This crystal structure has a high concentration of weak Lewis acid sites (coordinatively unsaturated tetrahedral ones on the surface of the material), which are deemed to be centers of dehydrogenation activity.\n          The assignment of Lewis acid sites as the active species was substantiated by Chen et al., who, by relating the results of NH3-TPD measurements with activity data for different GaxAl10xO15 mixed oxides, showed that a high concentration of Lewis acid groups in the form of coordinatively unsaturated tetrahedral Ga3+ cations is a prerequisite for dehydrogenation activity.\n          Xu et al. reported dehydrogenation activity on both Lewis and Brnsted acid sites on GaO3/H-ZSM-5. A zeolitic support displaying a low concentration of medium and strong acid sites and a relatively high concentration of weak acid sites was found to lead to the most active and stable catalyst.\n          Michorczyk et al. concluded that acidic groups catalyze the reaction after observing that promotion with a base, such as potassium, resulted in a decrease in activity.\n          The structure of the support is also important, as a mesoporous GaAl mixed oxide exhibited an increased resistance to catalyst coking.\n          The function of K was to reduce coke formation by poisoning Brnsted acid sites.\n          Pt is believed to act as a promoter for the GaOx. Indeed, albeit 1000 ppm Pt/Al2O3 was found to be virtually inactive, 1000 ppm of Pt in combination with 3 wt % Ga afforded conversions close to the equilibrium and an propylene selectivity <95%.\n          The role of Pt is to assist hydrogen desorption, which facilitates the regeneration of the gallium hydride hydroxide species.\n          The exact nature of the active sites in Ga-based dehydrogenation catalysts is still under debate.\n          The chemistry of molybdenum oxide is comparable to that of vanadium oxide, as Mo can be present as MoOx monomers, polymers, or MoO3 crystallites, depending on the molybdenum loading, the type of support used, and catalyst preparation conditions.\n          The reducibility of the catalyst with hydrogen prior to reaction increases conversion, although selectivity decreases due to the formation of acid sites.\n          The chemistry of molybdenum oxide is comparable to that of vanadium oxide, as Mo can be present as MoOx monomers, polymers, or MoO3 crystallites, depending on the molybdenum loading, the type of support used, and catalyst preparation conditions.\n          The reducibility of the catalyst with hydrogen prior to reaction increases conversion, although selectivity decreases due to the formation of acid sites.\n          The chemistry of molybdenum oxide is comparable to that of vanadium oxide, as Mo can be present as MoOx monomers, polymers, or MoO3 crystallites, depending on the molybdenum loading, the type of support used, and catalyst preparation conditions.\n          The reducibility of the catalyst with hydrogen prior to reaction increases conversion, although selectivity decreases due to the formation of acid sites.\n          The chemistry of molybdenum oxide is comparable to that of vanadium oxide, as Mo can be present as MoOx monomers, polymers, or MoO3 crystallites, depending on the molybdenum loading, the type of support used, and catalyst preparation conditions.\n          The reducibility of the catalyst with hydrogen prior to reaction increases conversion, although selectivity decreases due to the formation of acid sites.\n          The chemistry of molybdenum oxide is comparable to that of vanadium oxide, as Mo can be present as MoOx monomers, polymers, or MoO3 crystallites, depending on the molybdenum loading, the type of support used, and catalyst preparation conditions.\n          The reducibility of the catalyst with hydrogen prior to reaction increases conversion, although selectivity decreases due to the formation of acid sites.\n          The chemistry of molybdenum oxide is comparable to that of vanadium oxide, as Mo can be present as MoOx monomers, polymers, or MoO3 crystallites, depending on the molybdenum loading, the type of support used, and catalyst preparation conditions.\n          The reducibility of the catalyst with hydrogen prior to reaction increases conversion, although selectivity decreases due to the formation of acid sites.\n          The chemistry of molybdenum oxide is comparable to that of vanadium oxide, as Mo can be present as MoOx monomers, polymers, or MoO3 crystallites, depending on the molybdenum loading, the type of support used, and catalyst preparation conditions.\n          The reducibility of the catalyst with hydrogen prior to reaction increases conversion, although selectivity decreases due to the formation of acid sites.\n          Alumina is by far the most common support, and a variety of methods to produce chromiaalumina catalysts have been investigated.\n          The nature of the support is important not only because it governs the mechanical properties of the catalyst, but also because the interaction of the carrier with the active phase can have a profound impact on catalyst activity and selectivity.\n          Albeit selectivity has been found to be insensitive to chromium loading, it does change over time.\n          The use of zirconia as an alternative support has also been investigated.\n          The use of silica as the support in chromia-based dehydrogenation catalysts requires a relative high surface area to stabilize Cr6+ sites.\n          CrMgAl and CrMg mixed oxides prepared using layered double hydroxide (LDH) precursors have been studied as catalysts for the nonoxidative dehydrogenation of ethane.\n          Finally, the study of porous chromia-pillared α-zirconium phosphate materials has been particularly informative with regards to the influence that acidity has on catalytic behavior.\n          The surface area-to-metal loading ratio determines which species will form. Indeed, Wu et al. reported that monomeric species are predominantly present below 1.2 V/nm2, polymeric vanadium species prevail between 1.2 and 4.4 V/nm2, and crystalline V2O5 species preponderate at even higher loadings.\n          On the one hand, the presence of hydroxyl groups on the surface of the support is important to obtain a well-dispersed catalyst, as OH groups serve as anchoring sites for the vanadium precursors used to prepare these catalysts. On the other hand, acid sites are detrimental for catalyst performance, because they facilitate cracking and induce coke formation.\n          Alumina is commonly used as a support for vanadium oxide catalysts, although Sokolov et al. concluded through testing a wide range of Si- and Al-based supports that using silica to dope the alumina support provides beneficial effects on catalyst stability and activity.\n          Furthermore, as was shown by Harlin et al., the performance of supported vanadium catalysts can be improved through the addition of MgO, either as a promoter or as a component of a mixed oxide. According to these workers, the increase in dehydrogenation selectivity stems from the basic nature of MgO, resulting in reduced coke formation.\n          The reducibility of the vanadium species depends on their molecular structure, VOV and VO bonds being more easily reduced than VO-support bonds.\n          Prior to reaction, the vanadium in these catalysts is generally present as V5+. However, the reduction of the catalyst by the hydrocarbon feed results in the formation of V4+ and V3+.\n          Initially, deactivation is caused by the strong adsorption of reactants on the active sites and to a lesser extent to coke deposition.\n          When the coke is removed through the calcination of the catalyst, the latter may deactivate further as vanadium oxide species sinter and form larger V2O5 crystallites or mixed oxides such as AlVO4, both of which are less active.\n          V2O5 crystallites can revert to active polymeric vanadium species by treating the catalyst under an oxygen atmosphere at 600 C.\n          Different reasons for this beneficial effect of CO2 have been suggested, such as the removal of acid sites that catalyze unwanted side reactions, coke gasification, oxidation of overly reduced vanadium centers, and hydrogen removal by the reverse watergas shift reaction.\n          Ogonowski et al. reported that the effect of CO2 depends strongly on the catalyst support. Relatively weak basic sites on carriers, such as those present on an activated carbon support, facilitate the reverse water gas shift reaction, which lifts the thermodynamic limitation of the reaction and increases alkane conversion.\n          When these basic sites are too strong, as is the case on Al2O3 and ZnO2, CO2 irreversibly adsorbs and poisons these sites.\n          Alumina is commonly used as a support for vanadium oxide catalysts, although Sokolov et al. concluded through testing a wide range of Si- and Al-based supports that using silica to dope the alumina support provides beneficial effects on catalyst stability and activity.\n          Furthermore, as was shown by Harlin et al., the performance of supported vanadium catalysts can be improved through the addition of MgO, either as a promoter or as a component of a mixed oxide. According to these workers, the increase in dehydrogenation selectivity stems from the basic nature of MgO, resulting in reduced coke formation.\n          Alumina is by far the most common support, and a variety of methods to produce chromiaalumina catalysts have been investigated.\n          The nature of the support is important not only because it governs the mechanical properties of the catalyst, but also because the interaction of the carrier with the active phase can have a profound impact on catalyst activity and selectivity.\n          Albeit all of the noble metals of group VIIIB are active in the nonoxidative hydrogenation of alkanes, Pt is the only noble metal utilized in commercial applications due to its superior activation of paraffinic CH bonds and low activity to CC cleavage.\n          The addition of alkaline metals, such as Li, Na, and K, poisons these acid sites, suppressing the formation of coke on the support as shown in Figure 10.\n          The use of zirconia as an alternative support has also been investigated.\n          The use of silica as the support in chromia-based dehydrogenation catalysts requires a relative high surface area to stabilize Cr6+ sites.\n          CrMgAl and CrMg mixed oxides prepared using layered double hydroxide (LDH) precursors have been studied as catalysts for the nonoxidative dehydrogenation of ethane.\n          Finally, the study of porous chromia-pillared α-zirconium phosphate materials has been particularly informative with regards to the influence that acidity has on catalytic behavior.\n          The surface area-to-metal loading ratio determines which species will form. Indeed, Wu et al. reported that monomeric species are predominantly present below 1.2 V/nm2, polymeric vanadium species prevail between 1.2 and 4.4 V/nm2, and crystalline V2O5 species preponderate at even higher loadings.\n          On the one hand, the presence of hydroxyl groups on the surface of the support is important to obtain a well-dispersed catalyst, as OH groups serve as anchoring sites for the vanadium precursors used to prepare these catalysts.\n          On the contrary, large V2O5 crystallites are practically inactive in dehydrogenation.\n          Prior to reaction, the vanadium in these catalysts is generally present as V5+. However, the reduction of the catalyst by the hydrocarbon feed results in the formation of V4+ and V3+.\n          Initially, deactivation is caused by the strong adsorption of reactants on the active sites and to a lesser extent to coke deposition.\n          When the coke is removed through the calcination of the catalyst, the latter may deactivate further as vanadium oxide species sinter and form larger V2O5 crystallites or mixed oxides such as AlVO4, both of which are less active.\n          V2O5 crystallites can revert to active polymeric vanadium species by treating the catalyst under an oxygen atmosphere at 600 C.\n          Alumina is commonly used as a support for vanadium oxide catalysts, although Sokolov et al. concluded through testing a wide range of Si- and Al-based supports that using silica to dope the alumina support provides beneficial effects on catalyst stability and activity.\n          Furthermore, as was shown by Harlin et al., the performance of supported vanadium catalysts can be improved through the addition of MgO, either as a promoter or as a component of a mixed oxide. According to these workers, the increase in dehydrogenation selectivity stems from the basic nature of MgO, resulting in reduced coke formation.\n          Alumina is by far the most common support, and a variety of methods to produce chromiaalumina catalysts have been investigated.\n          The nature of the support is important not only because it governs the mechanical properties of the catalyst, but also because the interaction of the carrier with the active phase can have a profound impact on catalyst activity and selectivity.\n          Indeed, studies on the nonoxidative dehydrogenation of ethane have revealed that catalytic activity based on ethane conversion and ethylene yields follows the order CrOx/γ-Al2O3 > CrOx/SiO2 > CrOx/MCM-41  CrOx/MgO  CrOx/Si-2.\n          The use of zirconia as an alternative support has also been investigated.\n          The use of silica as the support in chromia-based dehydrogenation catalysts requires a relative high surface area to stabilize Cr6+ sites.\n          CrMgAl and CrMg mixed oxides prepared using layered double hydroxide (LDH) precursors have been studied as catalysts for the nonoxidative dehydrogenation of ethane.\n          Finally, the study of porous chromia-pillared α-zirconium phosphate materials has been particularly informative with regards to the influence that acidity has on catalytic behavior.\n          The surface area-to-metal loading ratio determines which species will form. Indeed, Wu et al. reported that monomeric species are predominantly present below 1.2 V/nm2, polymeric vanadium species prevail between 1.2 and 4.4 V/nm2, and crystalline V2O5 species preponderate at even higher loadings.\n          On the one hand, the presence of hydroxyl groups on the surface of the support is important to obtain a well-dispersed catalyst, as OH groups serve as anchoring sites for the vanadium precursors used to prepare these catalysts.\n          On the contrary, large V2O5 crystallites are practically inactive in dehydrogenation.\n          The reducibility of the vanadium species depends on their molecular structure, VOV and VO bonds being more easily reduced than VO-support bonds.\n          Prior to reaction, the vanadium in these catalysts is generally present as V5+. However, the reduction of the catalyst by the hydrocarbon feed results in the formation of V4+ and V3+.\n          Initially, deactivation is caused by the strong adsorption of reactants on the active sites and to a lesser extent to coke deposition.\n          When the coke is removed through the calcination of the catalyst, the latter may deactivate further as vanadium oxide species sinter and form larger V2O5 crystallites or mixed oxides, both of which are less active.\n          V2O5 crystallites can revert to active polymeric vanadium species by treating the catalyst under an oxygen atmosphere at 600 C.\n          Different reasons for this beneficial effect of CO2 have been suggested, such as the removal of acid sites that catalyze unwanted side reactions, coke gasification, oxidation of overly reduced vanadium centers, and hydrogen removal by the reverse watergas shift reaction.\n          Ogonowski et al. reported that the effect of CO2 depends strongly on the catalyst support. Indeed, Wu et al. reported that monomeric species are predominantly present below 1.2 V/nm2, polymeric vanadium species prevail between 1.2 and 4.4 V/nm2, and crystalline V2O5 species preponderate at even higher loadings.\n          On the one hand, the presence of hydroxyl groups on the surface of the support is important to obtain a well-dispersed catalyst, as OH groups serve as anchoring sites for the vanadium precursors used to prepare these catalysts.\n          On the contrary, large V2O5 crystallites are practically inactive in dehydrogenation.\n          The reducibility of the vanadium species depends on their molecular structure, VOV and VO bonds being more easily reduced than VO-support bonds.\n          Prior to reaction, the vanadium in these catalysts is generally present as V5+. However, the reduction of the catalyst by the hydrocarbon feed results in the formation of V4+ and V3+.\n          Initially, deactivation is caused by the strong adsorption of reactants on the active sites and to a lesser extent to coke deposition.\n          When the coke is removed through the calcination of the catalyst, the latter may deactivate further as vanadium oxide species sinter and form larger V2O5 crystallites or mixed oxides such as AlVO4, both of which are less active.\n          V2O5 crystallites can revert to active polymeric vanadium species by treating the catalyst under an oxygen atmosphere at 600 C.\n          The physicochemical properties of catalysts, including chemical qualities and morphological characteristics, significantly influence their performance in dehydrogenation reactions. For instance, the nature of the support material, such as alumina, zirconia, or silica, can affect the dispersion and stability of the active phase, thereby impacting the catalytic activity and selectivity. The interaction between the support and the active phase can also alter the electronic properties of the catalyst, which can further enhance its performance. Support modification strategies, such as doping with alkali metals or using mixed oxides, can optimize these properties for enhanced catalytic efficiency and selectivity. For example, doping with alkali metals can reduce surface acidity and increase the number of active sites, while using mixed oxides can improve thermal stability and coking resistance.", "English": "The physicochemical properties of catalysts, including chemical qualities and morphological characteristics, have a significant impact on their performance in dehydrogenation reactions. For example, the surface area-to-metal loading ratio determines the formation of different vanadium species, which affects the catalytic activity. The reducibility of vanadium species also influences the catalytic performance. The addition of MgO can improve the selectivity of vanadium-based catalysts by reducing coke formation. Using silica to dope alumina support can enhance the stability and activity of vanadium oxide catalysts. The type of support and preparation conditions can affect the formation of molybdenum oxide species. Hydrogen reduction can increase conversion but decrease selectivity due to the formation of acid sites. The structure of the support, such as mesoporous GaAl mixed oxide, can increase the resistance to catalyst coking. Poisoning Brnsted acid sites with K can reduce coke formation. Alumina is the most common support, and various methods have been explored to produce chromia-alumina catalysts. The choice of support can also influence the stability and dispersion of the active phase, which in turn affects the catalytic efficiency and selectivity. For example, zirconia has been investigated as an alternative support due to its low surface acidity and enhanced sintering resistance, which can improve the performance of chromia-based catalysts. The acidity of the support can also play a role in catalytic behavior, as demonstrated by the study of porous chromia-pillared α-zirconium phosphate materials. Support modification strategies, such as doping with alkali metals or using mixed oxides, can optimize these properties for enhanced catalytic efficiency and selectivity. For instance, doping with alkali metals can stabilize the structure of the support, reduce surface acidity, and increase the number of active sites. Using mixed oxides can also improve the thermal stability and coking resistance of the catalysts. The surface area-to-metal loading ratio determines the formation of monomeric, polymeric, or crystalline vanadium species on the catalyst. Hydroxyl groups on the support surface are important for anchoring vanadium precursors, while acid sites are detrimental to catalyst performance. Silica doping of alumina support can improve catalyst stability and activity. Addition of MgO can improve dehydrogenation selectivity by reducing coke formation. The reducibility of vanadium species depends on their molecular structure. Molybdenum oxide can exist as monomers, polymers, or crystallites, depending on loading, support, and preparation conditions. Optimal molybdenum oxide activity is achieved with monolayer coverage on alumina. Hydrogen reduction of molybdenum oxide catalyst increases conversion but decreases selectivity. Ga2O3 polymorphs, particularly β-Ga2O3, have high concentration of weak Lewis acid sites for dehydrogenation activity. Coordinatively unsaturated tetrahedral Ga3+ cations are crucial for dehydrogenation activity. High concentration of Lewis acid groups in the form of Ga3+ cations is necessary for dehydrogenation activity. Zeolitic support with low medium and strong acid sites and high weak acid sites leads to most active and stable GaO3/H-ZSM-5 catalyst. Promotion with a base like potassium decreases activity, indicating acidic groups catalyze the reaction. Mesoporous GaAl mixed oxide has increased resistance to coking. Potassium reduces coke formation by poisoning Brnsted acid sites. Platinum acts as a promoter for GaOx, enhancing conversion and selectivity. Platinum assists hydrogen desorption, facilitating regeneration of gallium hydride hydroxide species. The nature of active sites in Ga-based dehydrogenation catalysts is still under debate. Molybdenum oxide can exist as monomers, polymers, or crystallites, depending on loading, support, and preparation conditions. Hydrogen reduction of catalyst increases conversion but decreases selectivity due to acid site formation. The physicochemical properties of catalysts, including chemical qualities and morphological characteristics, significantly influence their performance in dehydrogenation reactions. Alumina is the most common support, and its interaction with the active phase can profoundly impact catalyst activity and selectivity. Noble metals, particularly platinum, are preferred for their superior activation of paraffinic CH bonds and low activity for CC cleavage. The addition of alkaline metals like lithium, sodium, and potassium can poison acid sites on the support, suppressing coke formation. Zirconia is an alternative support that has been investigated, offering low surface acidity and enhanced sintering resistance. Silica requires a high surface area to stabilize Cr6+ sites. Mixed oxides prepared using layered double hydroxide precursors have also been studied for nonoxidative dehydrogenation reactions. The acidity of the support material, such as in chromia-pillared α-zirconium phosphate, can significantly affect catalytic behavior. The physicochemical properties of catalysts, including chemical qualities and morphological characteristics, significantly influence their performance in dehydrogenation reactions. The surface area-to-metal loading ratio determines the formation of different vanadium species, which affects the catalytic activity. The presence of hydroxyl groups on the support surface is crucial for anchoring vanadium precursors, while large V2O5 crystallites are inactive in dehydrogenation. The reducibility of vanadium species depends on their molecular structure, and the reduction of the catalyst by the hydrocarbon feed results in the formation of V4+ and V3+. Initially, deactivation is caused by the strong adsorption of reactants on the active sites and coke deposition. The calcination of the catalyst can remove coke but may further deactivate the catalyst due to the formation of larger V2O5 crystallites or mixed oxides. V2O5 crystallites can revert to active polymeric vanadium species under certain conditions. The addition of CO2 can have a beneficial effect on the catalyst by removing acid sites, facilitating coke gasification, and promoting hydrogen removal. The effect of CO2 depends on the catalyst support, with relatively weak basic sites on activated carbon support facilitating the reverse water gas shift reaction, while strong basic sites on Al2O3 and ZnO2 can be poisoned by CO2. Using silica to dope the alumina support can improve catalyst stability and activity. The addition of MgO can improve the performance of supported vanadium catalysts by reducing coke formation. The physicochemical properties of catalysts, including chemical qualities and morphological characteristics, significantly influence their performance in dehydrogenation reactions. The nature of the support is crucial as it not only determines the mechanical properties of the catalyst but also affects the interaction between the carrier and the active phase, which can profoundly impact catalyst activity and selectivity. For instance, alumina is the most common support, and the method of producing chromia-alumina catalysts can vary, affecting the catalyst's performance. The choice of support can also influence the catalytic activity, with different supports leading to varying orders of activity based on conversion and yield. Zirconia, as an alternative support, has been investigated for its low surface acidity and enhanced sintering resistance. Silica requires a high surface area to stabilize Cr6+ sites, and mixed oxides prepared using layered double hydroxide precursors have been studied for their catalytic properties in dehydrogenation reactions. The acidity of the support, as seen in chromia-pillared α-zirconium phosphate materials, can also influence catalytic behavior, with strong acid sites affecting cracking reactions and medium strength acid sites impacting dehydrogenation reactions. Support modification strategies can be employed to optimize the properties of catalysts for enhanced catalytic efficiency and selectivity. For example, doping alumina-based dehydrogenation catalysts with alkali ions can effectively poison undesirable acid sites, improving selectivity. Using zirconia as a support can prevent the formation of mixed oxides and offer higher thermal stability and surface area. Silica, with its high surface area, can stabilize Cr6+ sites, while mixed oxides prepared using layered double hydroxide precursors can provide improved coking resistance and thermal stability against sintering. Understanding the role of acidity in catalytic behavior can also guide the modification of supports to favor dehydrogenation reactions over cracking reactions. The physicochemical properties of catalysts, including chemical qualities and morphological characteristics, significantly influence their performance in dehydrogenation reactions. For instance, the nature of the support material, such as alumina, zirconia, or silica, can affect the dispersion and stability of the active phase, thereby impacting the catalytic activity and selectivity. The interaction between the support and the active phase can also alter the electronic properties of the catalyst, which can further enhance its performance. Support modification strategies, such as doping with alkali metals or using mixed oxides, can optimize these properties for enhanced catalytic efficiency and selectivity. For example, doping with alkali metals can reduce surface acidity and increase the number of active sites, while using mixed oxides can improve thermal stability and coking resistance.", "Chinese": "催化剂的物理化学性质，包括化学品质和形态特征，对脱氢反应的性能有重大影响。例如，表面面积与金属负载比决定了不同钒物种的形成，这影响了催化活性。钒物种的还原性也影响催化性能。添加MgO可以提高钒基催化剂的选择性，减少焦炭形成。使用硅对氧化铝载体进行掺杂可以增强钒氧化物催化剂的稳定性和活性。载体类型和制备条件可以影响钼氧化物物种的形成。氢还原可以增加转化率，但会因酸性位点的形成而降低选择性。载体结构，如介孔GaAl混合氧化物，可以增加对催化剂焦炭的抵抗力。用K中毒Brnsted酸位点可以减少焦炭形成。氧化铝是最常见的载体，已经探索了各种方法来生产铬氧化铝催化剂。载体的选择也会影响活性相的稳定性和分散性，进而影响催化效率和选择性。例如，由于其低表面酸性和增强的烧结抗性，锆酸盐已被研究作为替代载体，可以改善铬基催化剂的性能。载体的酸性也可以在催化行为中发挥作用，正如多孔铬氧化物柱状α-磷酸锆材料的研究所示。通过载体改性策略，如用碱金属掺杂或使用混合氧化物，可以优化这些性质，以增强催化效率和选择性。例如，用碱金属掺杂可以稳定载体结构，降低表面酸性，并增加活性位点的数量。使用混合氧化物也可以提高催化剂的热稳定性和抗焦性。表面面积与金属负载比决定了催化剂上形成单体、聚合体或结晶钒物种。支持表面的羟基对于锚定钒前体很重要，而酸性位点对催化剂性能有害。硅酸盐掺杂氧化铝支持可以改善催化剂稳定性和活性。添加MgO可以提高脱氢选择性，减少焦炭形成。钒物种的还原性取决于其分子结构。钼氧化物可以存在为单体、聚合体或结晶体，取决于负载、支持和制备条件。在氧化铝上形成单层覆盖的钼氧化物可实现最佳活性。钼氧化物催化剂的氢还原增加了转化率，但降低了选择性。Ga2O3多晶型，特别是β-Ga2O3，具有高浓度的弱路易斯酸位点，用于脱氢活性。配位不饱和的四面体Ga3+离子对于脱氢活性至关重要。以Ga3+离子形式的高浓度路易斯酸基团是脱氢活性的必要条件。具有低中强酸位点和高弱酸位点的沸石支持导致最活跃和最稳定的GaO3/H-ZSM-5催化剂。用碱如钾的促进会降低活性，表明酸性位点催化反应。介孔GaAl混合氧化物具有增强的抗焦炭性。钾通过毒化布伦斯特酸位点减少焦炭形成。铂作为GaOx的促进剂，增强转化率和选择性。铂协助氢解吸，促进镓氢氧化物物种的再生。Ga基脱氢催化剂中活性位点的本质仍在争议中。钼氧化物可以存在为单体、聚合体或结晶体，取决于负载、支持和制备条件。催化剂的氢还原增加了转化率，但因酸位点的形成而降低了选择性。催化剂的物理化学性质，包括化学品质和形态特征，对脱氢反应的性能有重大影响。氧化铝是最常见的载体，它与活性相的相互作用可以深刻影响催化剂的活性和选择性。贵金属，尤其是铂，因其对烷烃CH键的优异活化和对CC键断裂的低活性而被优先选择。添加碱金属如锂、钠和钾可以毒化载体上的酸位点，抑制焦炭的形成。锆酸盐作为一种替代载体已被研究，它具有低表面酸性和增强的抗烧结性。二氧化硅作为载体需要相对高的表面积来稳定Cr6+位点。使用层状双氢氧化物前体制备的混合氧化物也被研究用于非氧化脱氢反应。载体材料的酸性，如在铬酸盐柱撑α-磷酸锆中，可以显著影响催化行为。催化剂的物理化学性质，包括化学品质和形态特征，对脱氢反应的性能有重大影响。表面面积与金属负载比决定了不同钒物种的形成，影响催化活性。支撑表面存在羟基对于锚定钒前体至关重要，而大V2O5晶体在脱氢中是不活跃的。钒物种的还原性取决于其分子结构，而催化剂通过烃类进料的还原会导致V4+和V3+的形成。最初，失活是由反应物在活性位点上的强烈吸附和焦炭沉积引起的。催化剂的煅烧可以去除焦炭，但可能会因形成更大的V2O5晶体或混合氧化物而进一步失活。V2O5晶体在一定条件下可以逆转为活性聚钒物种。添加CO2可以通过去除酸位点、促进焦炭气化和促进氢气去除对催化剂产生有益影响。CO2的影响取决于催化剂载体，相对弱的碱性位点在活性炭载体上可以促进逆水煤气变换反应，而Al2O3和ZnO2上的强碱性位点可以被CO2毒化。使用二氧化硅掺杂氧化铝载体可以改善催化剂的稳定性和活性。添加MgO可以改善支撑钒催化剂的性能，通过减少焦炭形成。催化剂的物理化学性质，包括化学品质和形态特征，对脱氢反应的性能有重大影响。载体的性质不仅决定了催化剂的机械性能，还影响了载体与活性相之间的相互作用，这可能对催化剂活性和选择性产生深远影响。例如，氧化铝是最常见的载体，生产氧化铬-氧化铝催化剂的方法可以变化，影响催化剂的性能。载体的选择也会影响催化活性，不同的载体会导致基于转化率和产量的不同活性顺序。作为替代载体，氧化锆因其低表面酸性和增强的抗烧结性而被研究。二氧化硅作为载体需要高表面积来稳定Cr6+位点，使用层状双氢氧化物前体制备的混合氧化物已被研究其在脱氢反应中的催化性质。载体的酸性，如在氧化铬-柱撑α-磷酸锆材料中所见，也会影响催化行为，强酸位点会影响裂化反应，中等强度酸位点会影响脱氢反应。可以通过载体改性策略来优化催化剂的性质，以提高催化效率和选择性。例如，用碱金属离子掺杂氧化铝基脱氢催化剂可以有效地毒化不希望的酸位点，提高选择性。使用氧化锆作为载体可以防止混合氧化物的形成，并提供更高的热稳定性和表面积。二氧化硅，由于其高表面积，可以稳定Cr6+位点，而使用层状双氢氧化物前体制备的混合氧化物可以提供改善的焦化抗性和抗烧结热稳定性。了解酸性在催化行为中的作用也可以指导载体的改性，以利于脱氢反应而不是裂化反应。催化剂的物理化学性质，包括化学品质和形态特征，对脱氢反应的性能有重大影响。例如，支撑材料的性质，如氧化铝、氧化锆或二氧化硅，可以影响活性相的分散和稳定性，从而影响催化活性和选择性。支撑材料与活性相之间的相互作用还可以改变催化剂的电子性质，从而进一步提高其性能。支撑材料改性策略，如用碱金属掺杂或使用混合氧化物，可以优化这些性质，以提高催化效率和选择性。例如，用碱金属掺杂可以降低表面酸性，增加活性位点的数量，而使用混合氧化物可以提高热稳定性和抗焦炭性能。", "Doi": "10.1021/cr5002436"},
{"Quotes": "<!-- Quotes for question 1 from all the answer results -->", "English": "The physicochemical properties of catalysts, including chemical qualities such as acid strength and stability, and morphological characteristics, significantly influence their performance in dehydrogenation reactions. The stability and tolerance to carbon deposits of Zr-Al-Beta promoted by alkali-metal ions were demonstrated. The modification of alkali-metal ions on both Lewis acid sites and Brnsted acid sites in Zr-Al-Beta was evidenced by XPS and FT-IR spectroscopy. The untreated materials displayed poor product selectivity and high coke deposit in the Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley reduction of furfural and isopropanol; however, the treatment of alkali-metal ions promoted their catalytic performance with improved recalcitrance to deactivation and coking significantly. The type of alkali-metal ions and the concentration of alkaline solution influenced the catalytic performance, which were found to correlate to the acidity and textual properties. The optimum reaction result (97.3% yield of furfuryl alcohol at 99.6% conversion of furfural) can be obtained on 0.025 M-Na+-Zr-Al-Beta with high tolerance to the furfural concentration. Support modification strategies can be employed to optimize these properties for enhanced catalytic efficiency and selectivity by tuning and normalizing the various acidic sites of zeolites. For instance, the post-synthetic method is demonstrated to be preferential to form open sites, which have stronger Lewis acidic properties than the closed sites. The simple post-synthetic strategy to prepare a Zr-Al-Beta zeolite with both plentiful Lewis acid open Zr (IV) sites and Brnsted acid sites has shown a superior catalytic activity, water-tolerance ability, and reusability in the cascade conversion of cinnamaldehyde toward 1-cinnamyl 2-propyl ether. The controllable tuning for the acid properties with various active sites is greatly required to promote some of the chemical transformations and avoid the possibility of other undesired reaction pathways except for the aimed reaction route, such as dehydration, polymerization, and isomerization.", "Chinese": "催化剂的物理化学性质，包括化学品质如酸强度和稳定性，以及形态特征，对脱氢反应的性能有重大影响。通过XPS和FT-IR光谱证实，碱金属离子对Zr-Al-Beta的Lewis酸位和Brnsted酸位进行了修饰。未经处理的材料在Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley还原反应中对糠醛和异丙醇的产物选择性差，且有大量焦炭沉积；然而，碱金属离子的处理显著提高了它们的催化性能，提高了对失活和结焦的抗性。碱金属离子的类型和碱性溶液的浓度影响催化性能，这与酸性和文本性质相关。在0.025 M-Na+-Zr-Al-Beta上，可以得到最佳反应结果（99.6%糠醛转化率下糠醇产量为97.3%），对糠醛浓度有很高的耐受性。通过调整和标准化沸石的各种酸位，可以采用载体改性策略来优化这些性质，以提高催化效率和选择性。例如，后合成方法被证明有利于形成开放位点，其Lewis酸性比封闭位点更强。通过简单的后合成策略制备的Zr-Al-Beta沸石，同时具有丰富的Lewis酸性开放Zr(IV)位点和Brnsted酸位点，在肉桂醛向1-肉桂基2-丙基醚的级联转化中表现出优异的催化活性、耐水性和可重复使用性。需要对具有各种活性位点的酸性进行可控调谐，以促进某些化学转化，并避免除目标反应途径外的其他不希望的反应途径，如脱水、聚合和异构化。", "Doi": "10.1016/j.jcat.2020.07.002"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The physicochemical properties of catalysts have a significant impact on their catalytic behaviors. Chemical qualities, including acid strength and hydrothermal and pH stability, affect the selectivity toward the targeted alkene in dehydrogenation reactions, while the morphological and porous qualities can influence the diffusion efficiency.\"\n          [2] \"In this section, strategies focused on support modification for dehydrogenation catalysts are summarized (Table 3).\"\n          [3] \"PDH is an acid-sensitive reaction, which signifies that proper acidity of the support is preferable for CH activation and propylene desorption, while unduly strong acidity, on the other hand, can generate a negative impact on the PDH process, possibly leading to CC cracking and deep dehydrogenation.\"\n          [4] \"As for zeolites, the Lewis acid sites are preferable for propane dehydrogenation, while the Brnsted acid sites are inductive factors in catalyzing cleavage reactions.\"\n          [5] \"For heterogeneous catalysts, one kinetic factor, the diffusion efficiency of the reactants and products, which is determined by the morphology, structure, size, and chemical properties of the supports, should be taken into consideration.\"\n          [6] \"Several strategies are proposed, focusing on shortening the diffusion path or diffusion resistance, including developing nanosized supports and synthesizing supports with particular morphologies and high external surfaces, e.g., needle-shaped, sheet-shaped, and mesh-shaped structures.\"", "English": "The physicochemical properties of catalysts, including chemical qualities and morphological characteristics, significantly impact their performance in dehydrogenation reactions. Chemical qualities, such as acid strength and stability, affect the selectivity toward the targeted alkene, while morphological and porous qualities influence the diffusion efficiency. Support modification strategies, summarized in Table 3, can optimize these properties for enhanced catalytic efficiency and selectivity. Proper acidity of the support is crucial for CH activation and propylene desorption in PDH reactions, while excessive acidity can lead to negative impacts such as CC cracking and deep dehydrogenation. For zeolites, Lewis acid sites are preferred for propane dehydrogenation, whereas Brnsted acid sites catalyze cleavage reactions. The diffusion efficiency of reactants and products in heterogeneous catalysts is determined by the morphology, structure, size, and chemical properties of the supports. Strategies to enhance catalytic efficiency include developing nanosized supports and synthesizing supports with specific morphologies and high external surfaces.", "Chinese": "催化剂的物理化学性质，包括化学品质和形态特征，对脱氢反应的性能有重大影响。化学品质，如酸强度和稳定性，影响对目标烯烃的选择性，而形态和多孔品质影响扩散效率。表3总结的支持修改策略可以优化这些性质，以提高催化效率和选择性。在PDH反应中，支持物的适当酸性对于CH活化和丙烯解吸至关重要，而过强的酸性可能会对PDH过程产生负面影响，可能导致CC裂解和深度脱氢。对于沸石，Lewis酸位点更适合丙烷脱氢，而Brnsted酸位点催化裂解反应。在异质催化剂中，反应物和产物的扩散效率由支持物的形态、结构、大小和化学性质决定。提高催化效率的策略包括开发纳米尺寸的支持物和合成具有特定形态和高外部表面的支持物。", "Doi": "10.1021/acscatal.3c00103_4"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"Different characterization techniques including H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, C3H6-TPD, XPS, BET, CO-chemisorption, CO-DRIFT, and TGA were used to unravel the properties of catalysts.\"\n          [2] \"Enhanced propylene selectivity (98.5% Vs 96.4% @ 600 C and 24 h TOS) and catalyst stability were achieved due to the decrease of acid centers of Al2O3 along with an increase of the degree of alloy formation upon addition of Ca.\"\n          [3] \"The experimental data of propane conversion vs. time were successfully fitted with the Deactivation Model with Residual Activity (DMRA), allowing for the calculation of the intrinsic deactivation kinetic parameters for both catalysts.\"\n          [4] \"For the Ca-promoted catalyst, a deactivation function of 0.05 h1 along with a residual activity of 0.82 at 600 C were obtained.\"\n          [5] \"Whereas, for the non-promoted sample, these values were 0.22 h1 and 0.63, respectively.\"\n          [6] \"The activation energy of the PDH reaction for the Pt0.5-Ge1.5/Al2O3-CaO catalyst was slightly higher than that of the unmodified one (74.8 kJ/mol vs. 66.4 kJ/mol) due to the enhanced reduction of the GeOx species on this sample, which enhanced the formation of a Pt-Ge alloy, decreasing the initial activity of the catalyst.\"\n          [7] \"However, the higher resistance against the deactivation by coke of the promoted catalyst was invoked to explain the better performance of this catalyst in terms both of activity and selectivity at steady state conditions.\"", "English": "The physicochemical properties of catalysts, including chemical qualities and morphological characteristics, significantly influence their performance in dehydrogenation reactions. The decrease of acid centers of Al2O3 and the increase of the degree of alloy formation upon addition of Ca lead to enhanced propylene selectivity and catalyst stability. The deactivation model with residual activity (DMRA) was used to fit the experimental data of propane conversion vs. time, which allowed for the calculation of the intrinsic deactivation kinetic parameters for both catalysts. The Ca-promoted catalyst showed a lower deactivation function and higher residual activity, indicating better resistance against deactivation by coke. The activation energy of the PDH reaction for the Ca-promoted catalyst was slightly higher due to the enhanced reduction of the GeOx species, which enhanced the formation of a Pt-Ge alloy, decreasing the initial activity of the catalyst. However, this also led to better performance in terms of both activity and selectivity at steady state conditions. Support modification strategies, such as the addition of Ca, can optimize these properties for enhanced catalytic efficiency and selectivity.", "Chinese": "催化剂的物理化学性质，包括化学品质和形态特征，对脱氢反应的性能有重大影响。添加Ca后，Al2O3的酸中心减少，Pt-Ge合金的形成程度增加，这导致丙烯选择性和催化剂稳定性的提高。使用具有残余活性的失活模型(DMRA)拟合了丙烷转化率与时间的实验数据，这使得能够计算两种催化剂的内在失活动力学参数。Ca促进的催化剂显示出较低的失活函数和较高的残余活性，表明对焦炭失活有更好的抵抗力。Ca促进的催化剂的PDH反应的活化能略高，这是由于GeOx物种的增强还原，这增强了Pt-Ge合金的形成，降低了催化剂的初始活性。然而，这也导致在稳态条件下，活性和选择性方面都有更好的性能。通过添加Ca等支持修改策略，可以优化这些性质，以提高催化效率和选择性。", "Doi": "10.1016/j.cej.2020.126656"},
{"Quotes": "The Lewis acid site arising from the unsaturated AlIII site in the Al2O3 structure is the active site for the catalytic cycle.\n          According to the NH3 desorption temperature, a majority of weak acid sites exist in γ-Al2O3-100 and θ-Al2O3-90, and a high level of strong acid sites is observable in γ-Al2O3-200.\n          The calculated acid site distribution in these samples is given in Table 1, and γ-Al2O3 possesses more Lewis acid sites than θ-Al2O3.\n          The propane conversion rate is positively linked to the amount of Lewis acid sites in Al2O3, which also indicates that the Lewis acid sites could be the active sites for propane dehydrogenation.\n          γ-Al2O3-200 catalyst shows the highest yield, which delivers an initial conversion of 48% and acid strength and stability, play a crucial role in their performance in dehydrogenation reactions. The Lewis acid site, arising from the unsaturated AlIII site in the Al2O3 structure, is the active site for the catalytic cycle. The amount of Lewis acid sites in Al2O3 is positively linked to the propane conversion rate, indicating their importance in propane dehydrogenation. Morphological characteristics, such as the crystalline structure, also influence catalytic performance. γ-Al2O3 possesses more Lewis acid sites than θ-Al2O3, which contributes to its higher activity. The regenerability of the γ-Al2O3-200 catalyst, which can be restored after deactivation, is an important property for practical applications. Support modification strategies, such as controlling the crystalline structure and increasing the number of Lewis acid sites, can be employed to optimize these properties for enhanced catalytic efficiency and selectivity.\n          The physicochemical properties of catalysts, including chemical qualities and morphological characteristics, significantly influence their performance in dehydrogenation reactions. The Lewis acid site, arising from the unsaturated AlIII site in the Al2O3 structure, is the active site for the catalytic cycle. The γ-Al2O3-200 catalyst, with a high level of strong acid sites, shows the highest yield in propane dehydrogenation. The formation of Lewis acid sites in Al2O3 is mainly due to the defective AIII site in the structure. The propane conversion rate is positively linked to the amount of Lewis acid sites in Al2O3, indicating that the Lewis acid sites are the active sites for propane dehydrogenation.\n          The physicochemical properties of catalysts, including chemical qualities and morphological characteristics, significantly influence their performance in dehydrogenation reactions. The Lewis acid site, arising from the unsaturated AlIII site in the Al2O3 structure, is the active site for the catalytic cycle. The amount of Lewis acid sites in Al2O3 is positively linked to the propane conversion rate. The γ-Al2O3-200 catalyst is regenerable, making it a sustainable catalyst for industrial application. Support modification strategies can be employed to optimize these properties for enhanced catalytic efficiency and selectivity.\n          The physicochemical properties of catalysts, including chemical qualities such as acid strength and stability, play a significant role in dehydrogenation reactions. The Lewis acid site, arising from the unsaturated AlIII site in the Al2O3 structure, is the active site for the catalytic cycle. γ-Al2O3 possesses more Lewis acid sites than θ-Al2O3, which contributes to its higher activity in propane dehydrogenation. The amount of Lewis acid sites in Al2O3 is positively linked to the propane conversion rate, indicating their importance as active sites for propane dehydrogenation. The Lewis acid site, arising from the unsaturated AlIII site in the Al2O3 structure, is the active site for the catalytic cycle. The amount of Lewis acid sites in Al2O3 is positively linked to the propane conversion rate, indicating their importance in propane dehydrogenation. Morphological characteristics, such as the crystalline structure, also influence catalytic performance. γ-Al2O3 possesses more Lewis acid sites than θ-Al2O3, contributing to its higher activity in propane dehydrogenation. Support modification strategies can be employed to optimize these properties for enhanced catalytic efficiency and selectivity by increasing the number of active sites and improving the stability of the catalyst.", "Chinese": "催化剂的物理化学性质，包括化学品质如酸强度和稳定性，在脱氢反应中的性能起着关键作用。来自Al2O3结构中未饱和AlIII位点的Lewis酸位点是催化循环的活性位点。Al2O3中的Lewis酸位点数量与丙烷转化率正相关，表明它们在丙烷脱氢中的重要性。形态特征，如晶体结构，也影响催化性能。γ-Al2O3的Lewis酸位点比θ-Al2O3多，这促成了其更高的活性。γ-Al2O3-200催化剂的可再生性，即可以在失活后恢复，对于实际应用是一个重要的性质。通过控制晶体结构和增加Lewis酸位点的数量，载体改性策略可以被用来优化这些性质，以提高催化效率和选择性。\n          催化剂的物理化学性质，包括化学品质和形态特征，对脱氢反应的性能有重大影响。Al2O3结构中来自未饱和AIII位点的Lewis酸位点是催化循环的活性位点。γ-Al2O3-200催化剂，具有高水平的强酸位点，在丙烷脱氢中显示出最高的产量。Al2O3中Lewis酸位点的形成主要是由于结构中AIII位点的缺陷。丙烷转化率与Al2O3中Lewis酸位点的数量正相关，表明Lewis酸位点是丙烷脱氢的活性位点。\n          催化剂的物理化学性质，包括化学性质和形态特征，对脱氢反应的性能有重大影响。Al2O3结构中来自未饱和AlIII位点的Lewis酸位点是催化循环的活性位点。γ-Al2O3-200催化剂，具有高水平的强酸位点，在丙烷脱氢中显示出最高的产量。Al2O3中Lewis酸位点的数量与丙烷转化率正相关。γ-Al2O3-200催化剂是可再生的，使其成为工业应用的可持续催化剂。可以通过支持修改策略来优化这些性质，以提高催化效率和选择性。\n          催化剂的物理化学性质，包括化学品质如酸强度和稳定性，在脱氢反应中起着重要作用。来自Al2O3结构中未饱和AlIII位点的Lewis酸位点是催化循环的活性位点。γ-Al2O3比θ-Al2O3具有更多的Lewis酸位点，这促使其在丙烷脱氢中具有更高的活性。Al2O3中Lewis酸位点的数量与丙烷转化率正相关，表明它们作为丙烷脱氢活性位点的重要性。γ-Al2O3-200催化剂的可再生性是可逆的，使其成为工业应用中可持续的催化剂。通过增加活性位点的数量和提高催化剂的稳定性，可以采用载体改性策略来优化这些性质，以提高催化效率和选择性。\n          催化剂的物理化学性质，包括化学性质如酸强度，在脱氢反应中起着重要作用。来自Al2O3结构中未饱和AlIII位点的Lewis酸位点是催化循环的活性位点。Al2O3中的Lewis酸位点数量与丙烷转化率正相关，表明它们在丙烷脱氢中的重要性。形态特征，如晶体结构，也影响催化性能。γ-Al2O3比θ-Al2O3具有更多的Lewis酸位点，这促成了其在丙烷脱氢中更高的活性。可以通过增加活性位点的数量和提高催化剂的稳定性来优化这些性质，以增强催化效率和选择性。", "Doi": "10.1039/D0CY00779J"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The synthesis procedure employed a diammonium-type bromide surfactant [C18H37N(CH3)2C6H12N(CH3)2C4H9Br2] and a sodium-free silica source.\"\n          [2] \"The presence of silanol nests in the resultant zeolite was confirmed by IR and NMR spectroscopies.\"\n          [3] \"When the zeolite was supported with 0.50 wt% Pt and 0.50 wt% Y using nitrate precursors, a remarkably long catalytic lifetime of 20 days was obtained with high propane conversion and propylene selectivity under the reaction condition using neat propane gas at 853 K.\"\n          [4] \"The Pt3Y alloy nanoparticles exhibited fully reversible hydrogen chemisorption behavior at room temperature, whereas the monometallic Pt nanoparticles showed only partially reversible chemisorption (4050% reversibility) due to the formation of a strong Pt-H bond.\"\n          [5] \"The PtY(0.5)/MZ-sf-Br and PtY(0.5)/MZ-sf-OH catalysts were even superior to PtY(0.5)/MZ-dg in terms of catalytic durability.\"\n          [6] \"The PtY(0.5)/MZ-sf-Br catalyst exhibited slow deactivation over 20 d as mentioned above, but PtY(0.5)/MZ-sf-Br-NaCl was deactivated within 1 d, similar to that of Pt(0.5)/MZ-sc.\"\n          [7] \"The mesoporous zeolite-supported Pt3Y catalyst deactivates slowly in propane dehydrogenation, maintaining high propane conversion and propylene selectivity, but the formation of the intermetallic compound requires atomistic migration of yttrium through silanol nests on the zeolite.\"\n          [8] \"The HAADF-STEM images show that the metal nanoparticles were homogeneously distributed throughout the support material in all cases.\"\n          [9] \"The size of the metal particles was approximately 2 nm for all four samples.\"\n          [10] \"The EDS analysis results confirmed that these metal nanoparticles contained both Pt and Y in the same particle.\"\n          [11] \"The average atomic ratio of Pt to Y was determined to be approximately 3 for both PtY(0.5)/MZ-sf-OH and PtY(0.5)/MZ-sf-Br samples, which agrees well with the Pt/Y ratio of Pt3Y intermetallic alloys supported on MZ-dg in a previous study.\"\n          [12] \"The conversion-vs-time plot in Fig. 6 a shows that the three PtY(0.5) catalysts supported on silanol nest-containing zeolites have an activation period (12 h) to reach the full conversion.\"\n          [13] \"The propane conversion was somewhat higher than the equilibrium value (42% at 853 K) during the early reaction period (e.g., < 7 d in PtY(0.5)/MZ-sf-Br).\"\n          [14] \"The TGA profile for the spent PtY(0.5)/MZ-sf-Br catalyst showed that 37 wt% of coke species were deposited on the catalyst sample.\"\n          [15] \"The measured spacing value of 0.403 nm corresponding to the Pt3Y L12 superlattice closely matched the known value of the Pt3Y bulk structure (i.e., 0.400 nm taken from PDF 00017-0058).\"\n          [16] \"The results show that there is an inverse relationship between the propane conversion and the metal loading amount when the catalysts were fully activated.\"\n          [17] \"The conversion-vs-loading relationship appears to originate from increasing metal dispersion (or decreasing particle size) at low loadings.\"\n          [18] \"The relatively low durability at low catalyst loading appears to be due to the increased fraction of the zeolite support in the catalyst.\"", "English": "The physicochemical properties of catalysts, including chemical qualities and morphological characteristics, significantly influence their performance in dehydrogenation reactions. The use of a diammonium-type bromide surfactant and a sodium-free silica source in the synthesis procedure leads to the formation of silanol nests in the zeolite, which are confirmed by IR and NMR spectroscopies. These silanol nests play a critical role in the formation of intermetallic alloy nanoparticles, such as Pt3Y, which exhibit high catalytic durability, high propane conversion, and propylene selectivity in propane dehydrogenation. The alloy nanoparticles show fully reversible hydrogen chemisorption behavior at room temperature, unlike monometallic Pt nanoparticles. The nanoparticles are homogeneously distributed throughout the support material, with a size of approximately 2 nm. The EDS analysis confirms that these metal nanoparticles contain both Pt and Y in the same particle, with an average atomic ratio of Pt to Y of approximately 3. The PtY(0.5)/MZ-sf-Br and PtY(0.5)/MZ-sf-OH catalysts show superior catalytic durability compared to PtY(0.5)/MZ-dg. The catalysts supported on silanol nest-containing zeolites have an activation period to reach full conversion. The propane conversion is higher than the equilibrium value during the early reaction period. The TGA profile for the spent PtY(0.5)/MZ-sf-Br catalyst shows that 37 wt% of coke species are deposited on the catalyst sample. The PtY(0.5)/MZ-sf-Br catalyst exhibits slow deactivation over 20 days, while PtY(0.5)/MZ-sf-Br-NaCl is deactivated within 1 day, similar to Pt(0.5)/MZ-sc. Support modification strategies, such as the use of a diammonium-type bromide surfactant and a sodium-free silica source, can optimize the properties of zeolite supports for enhanced catalytic efficiency and selectivity in dehydrogenation reactions.", "Chinese": "催化剂的物理化学性质，包括化学品质和形态特征，在脱氢反应中起着关键作用。使用双铵型溴化表面活性剂和无钠硅源的合成程序导致在最终的沸石中形成硅醇巢，这通过红外和核磁共振光谱学得到证实。当沸石被0.50 wt% Pt和0.50 wt% Y支撑时，这些硅醇巢促进了Pt3Y合金纳米颗粒的形成，导致长达20天的显著长催化寿命，具有高丙烷转化率和丙烯选择性。形成合金化合物需要钇原子通过沸石上的硅醇巢迁移。Pt3Y合金纳米颗粒在室温下表现出完全可逆的氢化学吸附行为，而单金属Pt纳米颗粒仅表现出部分可逆的化学吸附。金属纳米颗粒均匀分布在支撑材料中，大小约为2纳米。能量色散X射线光谱分析证实，这些金属纳米颗粒在同一颗粒中同时含有Pt和Y，Pt与Y的平均原子比约为3。PtY(0.5)/MZ-sf-Br和PtY(0.5)/MZ-sf-OH催化剂的催化耐久性优于PtY(0.5)/MZ-dg。在含有硅醇巢的沸石上支撑的催化剂有一个达到完全转化的激活期。在反应的早期阶段，丙烷转化率高于平衡值。PtY(0.5)/MZ-sf-Br催化剂的热重分析谱显示，37 wt%的焦炭物种沉积在催化剂样品上。PtY(0.5)/MZ-sf-Br催化剂在20天内缓慢失活，而PtY(0.5)/MZ-sf-Br-NaCl在1天内失活，类似于Pt(0.5)/MZ-sc。通过使用双铵型溴化表面活性剂和无钠硅源的支撑修改策略，可以优化沸石支撑的性质，以提高脱氢反应的催化效率和选择性。", "Doi": "10.1016/j.jcat.2021.09.011"},
{"Quotes": "\"CrOx supported on high-silica HZSM-5 with a SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of 260 (Cr/Z-5(260) is synthesized by a simple wet impregnation method, which exhibits high catalytic activity, good selectivity and excellent stability for PDH.\"\n          \"The exploitation of an efficient PDH catalyst based on HZSM-5 zeolite to achieve both high selectivity and stability is still a great challenge.\"\n          \"In zeolite supported catalysts, zeolite is usually not an inert support, which can provide a special environment (e.g., channel confinement effects, acidic sites and electron transfer) for catalytic reactions.\"\n          \"Especially, the acidic sites in zeolites play a key role in determining the catalytic performance of zeolite catalysts in alkane conversion.\"\n          \"The role of Cr species and Brnsted acid sites in Cr/HZSM-5 catalysts was elucidated on the basis of the physicochemical characterizations, PDH tests and Na+ doping experiments.\"\n          \"The structural properties of the prepared CrOx catalysts are detected by N2 sorption technique.\"\n          \"The XRD patterns of parent HZSM-5(260) and Cr/Z-5(260) samples are very similar, indicating that the Cr loading makes little influence on the crystallite structure of HZSM-5 zeolite.\"\n          \"The acidity properties of the prepared Cr/Z-5, Cr/SiO2 and Cr/Al2O3 catalysts are detected by NH3-TPD technique.\"\n          \"The metal-support interactions between Cr species and HZSM-5 support were measured by XPS spectroscopy.\"\n          \"During the PDH tests, the high reaction temperature would result in coke formation onto the catalyst, which is the main cause of catalyst deactivation.\"\n          \"The interactions between react/product molecules and catalysts are very important in dehydrogenation process.\"\n          \"The effect of Cr loading amount and SiO2/Al2O3 ratio on the catalytic performance of Cr/HZSM-5 catalysts was investigated in detail.\"\n          \"The role of Cr species and Brnsted acid sites in Cr/HZSM-5 catalysts was elucidated on the basis of the physicochemical characterizations, PDH tests and Na+ doping experiments.\"\n          \"Characterization results and Na+ doping experiments reveal that the Cr species combined with Brnsted acid sites in Cr/HZSM-5 catalysts are responsible for the high catalytic performance.\"\n          \"In particular, the Brnsted acid sites in HZSM-5 zeolite could increase the propane adsorption and enhance the CH bond activation.\"\n          \"Furthermore, the high surface area and well-defined pores of HZSM-5 zeolite can provide a special environment for the dispersion and stabilization of Cr species, thus guaranteeing high catalytic activity and stability.\"\n          \"The selection of supports for preparation of Cr-based catalysts for PDH is of great significance.\"\n          \"Zeolites, possessing high surface area, well-defined channels, good thermal stability and tunable acidity, can be used as catalysts or supports for various catalytic reactions.\"\n          \"The high amounts of acidic sites of HZSM-5 zeolites are negative for PDH reaction. Only HZSM-5 zeolite has suitable acidic sites that can be used as a good support for CrOx catalysts for PDH process.\"\n          \"The Brnsted acid sites play an important role in determining the catalytic performance of Cr/Z-5 catalyst system.\"\n          \"The Brnsted acid sites in HZSM-5(260) play a key role in propane adsorption and activation, affecting their catalytic performance.\"", "English": "The physicochemical properties of catalysts, including chemical qualities and morphological characteristics, significantly influence their performance in dehydrogenation reactions. Catalysts synthesized by wet impregnation method, such as CrOx supported on high-silica HZSM-5 with a SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of 260, exhibit high catalytic activity, good selectivity, and excellent stability for PDH. The exploitation of an efficient PDH catalyst based on HZSM-5 zeolite to achieve both high selectivity and stability is still a challenge. In zeolite supported catalysts, zeolite provides a special environment for catalytic reactions, including channel confinement effects, acidic sites, and electron transfer. Acidic sites in zeolites play a key role in determining the catalytic performance of zeolite catalysts in alkane conversion. The role of Cr species and Brnsted acid sites in Cr/HZSM-5 catalysts is elucidated through physicochemical characterizations, PDH tests, and Na+ doping experiments. The structural properties of the prepared CrOx catalysts are detected by N2 sorption technique. The XRD patterns of parent HZSM-5(260) and Cr/Z-5(260) samples are similar, indicating that the Cr loading has little influence on the crystallite structure of HZSM-5 zeolite. The acidity properties of the prepared Cr/Z-5, Cr/SiO2, and Cr/Al2O3 catalysts are detected by NH3-TPD technique. The metal-support interactions between Cr species and HZSM-5 support are measured by XPS spectroscopy. During the PDH tests, the high reaction temperature results in coke formation onto the catalyst, which is the main cause of catalyst deactivation. The interactions between react/product molecules and catalysts are very important in dehydrogenation process. The effect of Cr loading amount and SiO2/Al2O3 ratio on the catalytic performance of Cr/HZSM-5 catalysts is investigated in detail. The role of Cr species and Brnsted acid sites in Cr/HZSM-5 catalysts is elucidated through physicochemical characterizations, PDH tests, and Na+ doping experiments. Characterization results and Na+ doping experiments reveal that the Cr species combined with Brnsted acid sites in Cr/HZSM-5 catalysts are responsible for the high catalytic performance. The Brnsted acid sites in HZSM-5 zeolite increase propane adsorption and enhance CH bond activation. The high surface area and well-defined pores of HZSM-5 zeolite provide a special environment for the dispersion and stabilization of Cr species, ensuring high catalytic activity and stability. The selection of supports for Cr-based catalysts is crucial for PDH. Zeolites, with their high surface area, well-defined channels, good thermal stability, and tunable acidity, can serve as catalysts or supports for various catalytic reactions. The high amounts of acidic sites of HZSM-5 zeolites are negative for PDH reaction, and only HZSM-5 zeolite with suitable acidic sites can be used as a good support for CrOx catalysts for PDH process. The Brnsted acid sites play an important role in determining the catalytic performance of Cr/Z-5 catalyst system. The Brnsted acid sites in HZSM-5(260) play a key role in propane adsorption and activation, affecting their catalytic performance.", "Chinese": "催化剂的物理化学性质，包括化学品质和形态特征，对脱氢反应的性能有重大影响。通过湿浸渍法合成的催化剂，如CrOx在高硅HZSM-5上，SiO2/Al2O3比为260，对PDH表现出高催化活性、良好的选择性和优异的稳定性。基于HZSM-5沸石开发高效PDH催化剂，同时实现高选择性和稳定性，仍是一个挑战。在沸石支撑的催化剂中，沸石为催化反应提供了特殊的环境，包括通道限制效应、酸性位点和电子转移。沸石中的酸性位点在烷烃转化的沸石催化剂的催化性能中起着关键作用。Cr/HZSM-5催化剂中Cr物种和Brnsted酸位点的作用通过物理化学表征、PDH测试和Na+掺杂实验得以阐明。制备的CrOx催化剂的结构性质通过N2吸附技术检测。母体HZSM-5(260)和Cr/Z-5(260)样品的XRD图谱非常相似，表明Cr负载对HZSM-5沸石的晶粒结构影响很小。制备的Cr/Z-5、Cr/SiO2和Cr/Al2O3催化剂的酸性性质通过NH3-TPD技术检测。Cr物种和HZSM-5支撑之间的金属-支撑相互作用通过XPS光谱测量。在PDH测试中，高温导致催化剂上的焦炭形成，这是催化剂失活的主要原因。反应/产物分子与催化剂之间的相互作用在脱氢过程中非常重要。Cr/HZSM-5催化剂的催化性能受Cr负载量和SiO2/Al2O3比的影响进行了详细研究。Cr/HZSM-5催化剂中Cr物种和Brnsted酸位点的作用通过物理化学表征、PDH测试和Na+掺杂实验得以阐明。表征结果和Na+掺杂实验表明，Cr/HZSM-5催化剂中与Brnsted酸位点结合的Cr物种对高催化性能负责。HZSM-5沸石中的Brnsted酸位点增加了丙烷的吸附，增强了CH键的活化。HZSM-5沸石的高表面积和明确定义的孔隙为Cr物种的分散和稳定提供了特殊环境，从而确保了高催化活性和稳定性。Cr基催化剂的载体选择对PDH至关重要。沸石，具有高表面积、明确定义的通道、良好的热稳定性和可调酸度，可作为各种催化反应的催化剂或载体。HZSM-5沸石的高酸性位点对PDH反应是不利的，只有具有合适酸性位点的HZSM-5沸石才能作为CrOx催化剂的良好载体，用于PDH过程。Brnsted酸位点在确定Cr/Z-5催化剂系统的催化性能中起着重要作用。HZSM-5(260)中的Brnsted酸位点在丙烷吸附和活化中起关键作用，影响其催化性能。", "Doi": "10.1016/j.jechem.2019.12.010"},
{"Quotes": "The cationanion double hydrolysis approach (CADH), used for the synthesis of mesoporous Al2O3 with high surface area and a pure γ-Al2O3 phase, was undertaken with the crystallisation temperature varied between 25120 C.141 It was found that the crystallisation temperature of the support directly influenced the catalytic performance of the VOx/Al2O3 catalysts, which was a consequence of the increase in Lewis acid sites with increasing crystallization temperatures up to 100 C. This in turn affected the distribution of different surface V species.\nGu et al. reported that P modification could greatly influence the structure and activity of VOx/Al2O3 catalysts.142 More specifically, P modification decreased the degree of VOx polymerization, which had positive implications on the catalyst stability, as evidenced by the retention of high activity (ca. 45% propane conversion) after an 8 h DDH reaction in all P-modified catalysts.\nSubsequent studies on a VOx/Al2O3 catalysts (with 12 wt% V loading) modified with Mg revealed the anti-coking capability and improved catalytic performance evident through propene yields of 1927% over a 6 h DDH reaction.143 It was found that the dispersing action of Mg modification to V2O5 crystallites and an increase in active V3+ species reduced the amount and polymerization of coke deposits.\nThe concentration of dopant atoms, and the temperature of reduction were other contributing factors that affected the catalytic behaviour for ZrO2-based catalysts.3 Numerous binary YZrOx and LaZrOx-based catalysts displayed high activity, selectivity and stability as well as comparable performance to KCrOx/Al2O3 catalysts over the course of 60 DDH cycles at 550 C, 600 C and 625 C under industrially relevant conditions. The experimental parameters had a beneficial effect on the concentration of Zrcus4+ ions, and the concentration of surface lattice oxygen, which in tandem play an active role in propane activation.\nThe specific requirements of catalyst design for each sub-reaction are discussed and we identify that, regardless of the method of dehydrogenation, the balance of acid and base sites on the catalyst surface is of paramount importance.\nThe development of an active, selective and stable catalyst is essential for dehydrogenation to be considered as a viable process in the near- and long-term future.\nThe exact composition of the HGM is likely to include copper oxide and additional promotors such as MnO2, supported on α-Al2O3.\nThe role of Cu in the catalyst was to dilute the Pt species and promote desorption of propene, thereby enhancing selectivity.\nThe h-BN nanosheets provided abundant stacking fault edges terminated with BO defects that are associated with unpaired electrons, which strongly interact with active metal species, helping to strengthen the interaction between the metal and support.\nThe preparation of new catalysts with simultaneously enhanced activity, selectivity and stability is the ultimate goal.\nThe modification of Al2O3 with metal oxides, such as TiO2 has been undertaken with some promising results.\nThe enhanced performance was ascribed to electron transfer and acid site modulation effects resulting in changes to the adsorption properties of Pt.\nThe enhanced performance and stability was attributed to ultra-small, uniformly dispersed particles, ranging in size from 1.0 to 1.4 nm, consistent with previous studies that observed structure-sensitivity.\nThe role of the subsurface was to facilitate the activation of propane on the surface.\nThe role of the support is simply to maximise the active Cr6+ surface area, rather than add any chemical functionality, hence this is the reason why chemically-unreactive supports such as SiO2 and activated carbon yield the most active CrOX catalysts.\nThe most significant barrier to commercial application is the poor on-stream stability exhibited by all chromium-based catalysts.\nThe stability was improved in the presence of CO2 (compared to DDH); ca. 74% of the original activity was retained after 10 h on-stream, which is relatively good compared to Ga- and Cr-based catalysts.\nThe origin of stability was linked to the low rate of coking associated with the spinel catalyst.\nThe role of CO2 in ODH-CO2 is to assist the above equilibrium by removing H2via the RWGS reaction.\nThe origin of this induction period was found to be reduction of In2O3 to In0 nanoclusters, which suggests the active structure is more of a supported nanoparticle type catalyst than a mixed-metal oxide.\nThe basicity of the In/ZrO2 system was suggested to promote the RWGS reaction, which in turn boosted the ODH-CO2 activity.\nThe initial STY of this catalyst was 10.7 molC3H6 kgcat1 h1 (Table 13, entry 4), which is amongst the most active reported to date, but requires significant improvements to its on-stream stability.\nDespite the low selectivity, the FeCeO2 catalysts exhibited a comparable STY to supported In2O3 (Table 13) and some Ga2O3 catalysts (Table 12).\nThe major side-reactions observed were dry reforming and cracking.\nThe cationanion double hydrolysis approach (CADH), used for the synthesis of mesoporous Al2O3 with high surface area and a pure γ-Al2O3 phase, was undertaken with the crystallisation temperature varied between 25120 C.141 It was found that the crystallisation temperature of the support directly influenced the catalytic performance of the VOx/Al2O3 catalysts, which was a consequence of the increase in Lewis acid sites with increasing crystallization temperatures up to 100 C. This in turn affected the distribution of different surface V species.\nThe authors concluded that the relative proportions of V3+, V4+ and V5+ species present on the catalyst surface were affected by V loading and at the optimal loading of 12 wt%, a high concentration of isolated V3+ species was detected.\nGu et al. reported that P modification could greatly influence the structure and activity of VOx/Al2O3 catalysts.142 More specifically, P modification decreased the degree of VOx polymerization, which had positive implications on the catalyst stability, as evidenced by the retention of high activity (ca. 45% propane conversion) after an 8 h DDH reaction in all P-modified catalysts.\nThe combined and synergistic effect of the surface acidity modifications, their influence on the active V3+ species, and weakened metalsupport interactions facilitated desorption of propene and inhibited the deep dehydrogenation that leads to coke precursors.\nSubsequent studies on a VOx/Al2O3 catalysts (with 12 wt% V loading) modified with Mg revealed the anti-coking capability and improved catalytic performance evident through propene yields of 1927% over a 6 h DDH reaction.143 It was found that the dispersing action of Mg modification to V2O5 crystallites and an increase in active V3+ species reduced the amount and polymerization of coke deposits.\nThe highest STY achieved was 7.8 molC3H6 kg1cat h1 (Table 6, entry 7).\nThe moderate vanadium doping level was conducive to highly dispersed vanadium species in the form of isolated and low-polymerized VOx species.\nHighly dispersed and stable VOx species, and an absence of V2O5 crystallites, were conducive to high catalytic activity and stability.\nThe STY was 6.2 molC3H6 kg1cat h1 (Table 6, entry 5), due to the low GHSV so while the catalyst achieved high selectivity at reasonable propane conversion, it was not as intrinsically active as other supported VOx catalysts.\nThe most active catalyst, V/Si-beta (having 3 wt% V loading) displayed an initial propene yield of 33.4% and retained activity over multiple dehydrogenationregeneration cycles.\nThe STY was 4.4 molC3H6 kg1cat h1 (Table 6, entry 6), which is 56 times less active than the most active VOx catalysts reported to date, suggesting that Si-beta does not facilitate a high concentration of active V sites.\nIt was found that VOx/ZrO2 is approximately five times more active than VOx/Al2O3 and pure ZrO2, exhibiting a STY of 9.2 molC3H6 kg1cat h1 (Table 6, entry 2).\nThe authors proposed that the enhanced performance of VOx/ZrO2 results from the facile reduction of VO, VOV and VOZr bonds, thus producing higher proportions of the active V3+ species.\nFor the most active catalyst, with 8 wt% V loading, the initial yield of propene increased from 24% at 550 C to 28% at 575 C with a negligible (<1%) increase at 600 C.\nThis corresponded to a STY of 24 molC3H6 kg1cat h1 (Table 6, entry 3), which is one of the most active VOx-based catalysts reported.\nThe STY of ZrO2 without VOx is actually much higher than in the current work.\nThe most active V species has been identified, the relative proportion and stability of this surface V species can be tuned by varying the preparation method.\nThe role of the other V species on the DDH reaction remains unclear so further work to elucidate this could yield more active and stable DDH catalysts.\nThe range in performance of V-based catalysts varies quite significantly, with the most active catalysts exhibiting STYs that are around 34 time less active than the most active Pt catalysts.\nThe specific requirements of catalyst design for each sub-reaction are discussed and we identify that, regardless of the method of dehydrogenation, the balance of acid and base sites on the catalyst surface is of paramount importance.\nThe development of an active, selective and stable catalyst is essential for dehydrogenation to be considered as a viable process in the near- and long-term future.\nIn the case of SC and coal-based MTO, this is unavoidable due to the nature of the feedstock. However, natural gas and propane can be produced from biomass. In these cases, the feedstock is renewable and so these processes are potentially much more sustainable than when using fossil fuels.\nThe majority of analyses focus on well-established processes, where more information and data are available, but no such analyses were found for oxidative dehydrogenation.\nThe thermodynamic tendency to form undesirable by-products means that such reactions must be carefully kinetically controlled. Careful catalyst design can inhibit and even switch-off some of these side-reactions, as will be discussed in the subsequent sections.\nThe exact composition of the HGM is likely to include copper oxide and additional promotors such as MnO2, supported on α-Al2O3.\nThe role of Cu in the catalyst was to dilute the Pt species and promote desorption of propene, thereby enhancing selectivity.\nThe role of the subsurface was to facilitate the activation of propane on the surface.\nThe preparation strategy could greatly influence the structure of Ga/SiO2 catalysts.\nThe preparation of GaRh supported catalytically active liquid metal solutions.\nThe GaPt alloy melts at temperatures between 270 C and 330 C.\nThe activity is dependent on the bond strength of the VOsupport bond.\nThe metalsupport (VOsupport) interactions affect the resultant catalyst performance.\nThe catalyst deactivated quickly due to carbon deposition, but retained its initial activity over the course of ten successive dehydrogenationregeneration cycles.\nThe first study of Cr2O3-based catalysts for ODH-CO2 was reported by Takahara et al. in 1996 using Cr2O3 supported on SiO2, activated carbon (AC) or Al2O3.\nIt was found that over 5 wt% Cr2O3/SiO2, the propene yield increased from 6.5% to 9.1% when CO2 was co-fed instead of Ar.\nIn contrast, the alumina supported catalyst was inhibited by the addition of CO2, as shown by the drop in propene yield from 12.7% to 3.3%.\nThe 5 wt% Cr2O3/AC material was unaffected by CO2 addition.\nThe Cr2O3/SiO2 catalyst deactivated rapidly, retaining just 66% of its original activity after 4 h on-stream.\nThe stability was noted to the same with or without CO2 in the reactant feed.\nNot only did this study establish Cr2O3 as an active ODH-CO2 catalyst, it also captured one of the recurring themes in catalyst design for ODH-CO2: some catalysts are inhibited by the addition of CO2 while others perform much better.\nRelative to many other metal oxides, Cr2O3 is considered to be one of the most promising catalysts for ODH-CO2.\nTakehira et al. compared the catalytic performance of several d block and p block oxides (namely Cr, Ga, Ni, V, Fe, Mn and Co) supported on MCM-41, at 550 C with a CO2:C3H8 molar ratio of 5.6.\nAfter 30 min on-stream, the propene yield of the Cr-based catalyst was 15% whereas for the Ga-based counterpart it was 5%.\nThe remaining catalysts all exhibited lower propene yields (in the 14% range).\nHowever, as the catalysts were not characterised, it is unclear if the dispersion of these catalysts was comparable, and therefore if the results reflect the true intrinsic activity of each metal.\nIt was also noted that the order of reactivity resembled the trends observed by Nakagawa et al. for diamond-supported metal catalysts in the DDH reaction.\nThis suggests that there are commonalities in catalyst design between DDH and ODH-CO2 which most likely relate to the interaction of the alkane with the catalyst.\nContrary to this, Zhang et al. compared ZrO2, SBA-15 and γ-Al2O3 as supports for Cr2O3 in the DDH, ODH-CO2 and ODH-O2 reactions.\nThey found that the highest propene yield was observed with different catalyst systems under different dehydrogenation reactions, i.e., the activity trends in DDH did not translate to ODH-CO2 catalysts.\nSpecifically, Cr2O3/ZrO2 catalyst was the most active for the DDH reaction, while the highest yield of propene for the ODH-CO2 and ODH-O2 reactions was observed over Cr2O3/SBA-15 (Table 11, entry 7).\nAcross all the catalysts however, the highest propene yields were generally observed in the DDH reaction, ascribed to the production of carbon oxides in the ODH-O2 and ODH-CO2 reactions.\nHowever, it was reported that Cr2O3/ZrO2 was more stable on-stream in ODH-CO2 than in the DDH reaction.\nWu et al. also observed increased stability of Cr2O3/ZrO2 in the presence of CO2 (Table 11, entry 4).\nThey reported that the CO formation rate was higher than the CO2 consumption rate and the excess CO was suggested to originate from the Boudouard reaction (CO2 + C  2CO); this could explain the increased stability of this catalyst.\nIt is possible that some dry reforming of propane also took place, which would produce H2 and CO.\nZhao et al. recently reported the facile preparation of Cr supported in mesoporous ZrO2 using an evaporation-induced self-assembly method (Table 11, entry 6).\nThe authors suggested that propene could react with carbon dioxide to form carbon monoxide, methane and water.\nOther studies have reported a stronger inhibition effect for Cr2O3/ZrO2 catalysts in the presence of CO2.\nFor instance, Ferreira et al. studied the adsorption properties of CO2 and concluded that it binds strongly to active Cr2O3 sites, lowering the activity and stability of the catalyst,\nwhereas Xie et al. suggested that coke formation could originate from CO2 hydrogenation over Cr2+ species.\nThese conflicting reports may relate to the structural polymorph of ZrO2 present in the catalyst support; this factor is often overlooked, but recent studies from Kondratenko et al. revealed that nanocrystalline ZrO2 is an active DDH catalyst in its own right151,152 under similar reaction conditions.\nThe ZrO2 crystal phase and crystallite size were strongly correlated to the catalyst activity: smaller crystallites were more active but amorphous ZrO2 had very low intrinsic activity.\nMoreover, monoclinic ZrO2 was more active than tetragonal ZrO2.\nCr2O3-catalysed ODH-CO2 has been examined over different polymorphs of SiO2,254256 including various structured porous oxides, including SBA-1,84 SBA-15,250,257 MCM-41,91 amorphous silica84 and mesoporous silica spheres.258\nNotably, Michorczyk et al. reported a detailed comparison of different silica supports, coupled with an in-depth characterisation study.84\nIt was shown that in each case, the same active Cr species was formed, namely Cr6+, but higher surface area silicas (e.g., SBA-1 and SBA-15) were able to facilitate a higher number of such sites.\nA clear correlation was found between the rate of propene formation and the wt% of Cr6+, as determined using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS).\nIn DDH, while Cr6+ is considered active, under reaction conditions Cr3+ is rapidly formed and considered the principle active species.93,94\nThe selectivity to propene was similar across the different silica supports (8893%), with the observed differences being attributable to differences in propane conversion rather than catalytic properties.\nThese Cr2O3/SiO2 catalysts were highly active at 550 C and the most active catalyst (Cr2O3/SBA-1) achieved a STY of 7.9 molC3H6 kgcat1 h1, as shown in Table 11, entry 12.\nIt should be noted that the experiments were carried out with a CO2:C3H8 ratio of 5, which as discussed above, has been shown to enable a higher equilibrium yield of propene.\nTherefore, in studies where high conversions are generally targeted and carbon dioxide is in excess of propane, higher propene yields are reported.\nTakehira et al. carried out X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) on CrOx/MCM-41, confirming that the reduction of Cr6+ occurs during the reaction.91\nSpecifically, they identified Cr6+O4 tetrahedra as the active species.\nThese Cr3+O6 octahedra were formed after reduction, which were considered to be less active.\nIt was shown that CO2 could re-oxidise the Cr, which suggests that the redox cycle between Cr6+ and Cr3+ is an important process during the reaction.\nYi et al. discriminated between isolated Cr6+ and polymeric Cr6+, finding that after reduction, isolated Cr3+ was more active than polymeric Cr3+. This underlines the importance of Cr dispersion in these catalysts.259\nIn a more detailed examination of Cr2O3/SBA-1, the relationship between the physicochemical properties of the catalyst and the observed activity were explored.85\nMichorczyk et al. found a strong positive correlation between the initial propene yield and the reducibility of the catalyst, specifically the H2 consumption.\nIn situ UV-vis measurements revealed that Cr6+ is rapidly reduced to Cr3+ or Cr2+ in the presence of C3H8 under reaction conditions.\nThe reaction proceeds through a Mars-Van Krevelen mechanism, via the Cr2+/3+ redox couple.\nRapid deactivation, typical of Cr2O3 catalysts, was observed, although the majority of the initial activity could be recovered after regeneration in air.\nThe remainder was ascribed to pore collapse and/or the formation of inactive Cr sites, although the loss of surface Cr sites through agglomeration was not considered.\nDespite early reports that activated carbon (AC) was not a suitable support for Cr2O3, subsequent studies have shown that above 550 C, the activity of Cr2O3/AC in the presence of CO2 was higher than in the DDH reaction.260\nThe enhancement in propane conversion due to the presence of CO2 increased at higher temperatures (i.e., above 600 C), although this was chiefly due to propane dry reforming proceeding, generating CO and H2 rather than propene.\nWhile this Cr2O3/AC exhibited the highest STY of propene out of all CrOx-based catalysts (21 molC3H6 kgcat1 h1, Table 11, entry 9), it rapidly deactivated on-stream and due to the support being carbonaceous, cannot be regenerated using air.\nThis severely limits the utility of this catalyst.\nZeolites have also been considered as catalyst supports for Cr2O3.\nZhang et al. prepared CrOx/Na-ZSM-5 via incipient wetness.261\nAlthough the initial conversion and selectivity was high (48% and 86%, respectively) (Table 11, entry 5), the catalysts deactivated rapidly and the reaction conditions were such that the STY was only 2.5 molC3H6 kgcat1 h1 at 550 C with a CO2:C3H8 ratio of 2.\nZhu et al. investigated a range of MFI supports, including silicalite-1 and H[B]MFI.262\nCrOx/H[B]MFI was found to be the most active catalyst, giving a STY of 4.7 molC3H6 kgcat1 h1 at 600 C with a CO2:C3H8 of 1 (Table 11, entry 15).\nAlthough the as-prepared catalyst exhibited typically poor stability for Cr catalysts, steam treating the catalyst resulted in a marked improvement.\nAfter 60 h on-stream, the as-prepared catalyst retained only 25% of its initial conversion, while the steam treated catalyst retained ca. 74%.\nThe authors ascribed the effect to stabilised Cr3+ formed in the steam treatment.\nPresumably the reduction of Cr6+ during the reaction results in an inactive or less active Cr3+ species.\nIt should also be noted that the as-prepared catalyst was initially almost twice as active as the steam treated catalyst, which leaves the possibility that at higher conversions, increased coke formation may have occurred which would exaggerate the deactivation compared to the steam treated catalyst.\nIdeally such stability comparisons
