would be made at isoconversion, however this discovery is one of only a few that shows improved stability on-stream.\nRecently, Michorczyk et al. prepared a Cr-β-zeolite and investigated the effect of dealumination, which clearly elucidated the effect of acidity on the catalytic performance.263\nIt was reported that the dealuminated catalyst, Cr-SiBeta, exhibited significantly higher propene yields (up to 27%), compared to the Al-containing catalyst, Cr-AlBeta (2%).\nThe presence of acid sites in the Cr-AlBeta catalyst resulted in cracking pathways that led to increased production of methane and ethene.\nMoreover, the CrAlbeta catalyst performed less well in the presence of CO2 than in the DDH reaction.\nThis was explained by the strong adsorption of CO2 on the catalyst, similar to the inhibition observed over Cr2O3/Al2O3 catalysts.\nThe stability of the dealuminated catalyst was also improved compared with CrAlbeta, but significant loss in activity was observed over the 4 h reaction.\nIn considering the redox properties of the catalysts in this work, and their previous investigations, the authors also identified a strong correlation between the H2 consumption from H2-TPR studies and the reported propene yield, as shown in Fig. 10.\nWhile the majority of investigations on ODH-CO2 Cr2O3 catalysts have focused on support modifications, the addition of a promotor has also been shown to be beneficial.\nYun et al. demonstrated that the addition of 0.5 wt% Ni to a 10 wt% CrOx/SBA-15 catalyst increased the propane and CO2 conversion, as well as the on-stream stability.264\nAfter 1 h on-stream, the Ni-promoted catalyst was 50% more active and the conversion and selectivity was almost maintained over 12 h on-stream.\nIn contrast, the less active unpromoted catalyst retained only half of the initial activity over the same time period.\nUsing three-stage H2-TPR experiments (where the catalyst is reduced twice under H2 and then re-oxidised in CO2 before the final H2-TPR program), the authors showed that the addition of Ni facilitated the re-oxidation of Cr during the reaction.\nThis is consistent with previously reported mechanisms of deactivation over Cr-based catalysts, although coking is also often reported to cause deactivation.\nInterestingly, the promoted catalyst was marginally more prone to coking.\nThis strongly suggests that overreduction of active Cr sites is the key deactivation mechanism over these catalysts.\nThere is a lot of potential to develop promoted Cr catalysts that could enhance the redox activity of the catalyst; precious metals including Pd and Pt are often supported on reducible supports for this purpose.265\nCrucially, it was found that above 0.5 wt% Ni, propane reforming was prevalent, which underlines the importance of appropriate loadings of promotors.\nO'Brien et al. investigated the effect of a Ru promoter to a 10 wt% CrOx/SiO2 catalyst.\nConsistent with Yun et al. it was shown that the propene formation rate was increased.\nA 1 wt% Ru loading was optimal and doubled the activity.\nInterestingly, this is approximately the same molar ratio reported as the optimum by Yun et al. for Ni-promoted CrOx/SBA-15 (Table 11, entry 14).\nAnother similarity was the propensity of reforming to dominate at high loadings (>1 wt%).\nThe enhanced stability seen in Ni-promoted Cr catalysts was not observed in this work and the activity could not be fully recovered after regeneration.\nConsequently, aggregation of Cr species was suggested as an additional deactivation mechanism in addition to coke formation and overreduction of Cr.\nRather than aid Cr re-oxidation in a one-step oxidative dehydrogenation, the authors concluded that the Ru promotes the RWGS reaction, which removes H2 and increases the equilibrium conversion of propane.\nHowever, the results of three-stage H2-TPR reactions indicated that Cr can be more easily oxidised in the presence of Ru, which suggests that Ru can participate in a similar role as Ni-promoted Cr catalysts.\nOverall supported chromium oxide catalysts represent one of the most active classes of ODH-CO2 catalysts, with STY values in the range of 222 molC3H6 kgcat1 h1.\nThe role of the support is simply to maximise the active Cr6+ surface area, rather than add any chemical functionality, hence this is the reason why chemically-unreactive supports such as SiO2 and activated carbon yield the most active CrOX catalysts.\nThe most significant barrier to commercial application is the poor on-stream stability exhibited by all chromium-based catalysts.\nWhile incremental improvements in the activity of Cr catalysts have been reported since their initial discovery, significant advances in catalyst stability have been relatively few.\nThe first study of Cr2O3-based catalysts for ODH-CO2 was reported by Takahara et al. in 1996 using Cr2O3 supported on SiO2, activated carbon (AC) or Al2O3.\nThe 5 wt% Cr2O3/SiO2 catalyst deactivated rapidly, retaining just 66% of its original activity after 4 h on-stream.\nThe stability was noted to the same with or without CO2 in the reactant feed.\nNot only did this study establish Cr2O3 as an active ODH-CO2 catalyst, it also captured one of the recurring themes in catalyst design for ODH-CO2: some catalysts are inhibited by the addition of CO2 while others perform much better.\nThe correct balance of acidic and basic sites is a key consideration in catalyst design.\nEqually, the ratio of carbon dioxide to propane is important to take in account, as it has kinetic and thermodynamic implications.\nThermodynamically, higher CO2:C3H8 ratios limit coke forming side-reactions.\nThe addition of CO2 in the dehydrogenation reaction has multiple effects: As discussed in Section 2, it facilitates the RWGS reaction which removes H2 from the system and shifts the thermodynamic equilibrium limit to favour propene production.\nAdditionally, CO2 can dissociate on the surface of a catalyst and provide O species to dehydrogenate propane directly.\nFinally, it can react with coke via the reverse-Boudouard reaction to produce CO, which can potentially extend the lifetime of the catalyst.\nThe role of the support is simply to maximise the active Cr6+ surface area, rather than add any chemical functionality, hence this is the reason why chemically-unreactive supports such as SiO2 and activated carbon yield the most active CrOX catalysts.\nThe most significant barrier to commercial application is the poor on-stream stability exhibited by all chromium-based catalysts.\nWhile incremental improvements in the activity of Cr catalysts have been reported since their initial discovery, significant advances in catalyst stability have been relatively few.\nThe addition of Al2O3 to ODH-CO2 catalysts is typically not beneficial.\nAlthough the addition of Al2O3 to ODH-CO2 catalysts is typically not beneficial, Chen et al. investigated spinel-type Ga2O3Al2O3 mixed oxides and showed that they can function as stable catalysts.\nThe origin of stability was linked to the low rate of coking associated with the spinel catalyst.\nUsing NH3-TPD analysis, the authors concluded that weak Lewis acid sites were conducive to high activity.\nThese acidbase properties most likely contribute to the enhanced stability as well; it is known that stronger acid sites promote oligomerisation pathways that produce coke.\nThe increased performance of Ga2O3/ZSM-48 was attributed to the abundance of weak and medium strength acid sites.\nThe low activity of Ga2O3/MgO and Ga2O3/SiO2 was ascribed to the absence of medium and strong acid sites.\nIn the Ga2O3/TiO2 catalyst, a significant proportion of the Ga (45%) was reduced.\nThis catalyst exhibited the highest propane conversion, but with a propene selectivity of 73% it did not result in the highest propene yield.\nThe origin of this induction period was found to be reduction of In2O3 to In0 nanoclusters, which suggests the active structure is more of a supported nanoparticle type catalyst than a mixed-metal oxide.\nThe basicity of the In/ZrO2 system was suggested to promote the RWGS reaction, which in turn boosted the ODH-CO2 activity.\nIt was found that 10 mol% Fe in CeO2 exhibited the highest propene yield.\nThe major side-reactions observed were dry reforming and cracking.\nThey showed that reforming pathways were more prevalent at higher CO2:C3H8 ratios, such as 2.5:1 and 5:1.\nDespite the low selectivity, the FeCeO2 catalysts exhibited a comparable STY to supported In2O3 and some Ga2O3 catalysts.\nThe number of studies on supported nanoparticle catalysts for ODH-CO2 are relatively few and those available indicate that this field of research has great potential.\nThe major challenge is in understanding and inhibiting side-reactions such as reforming, which are known to proceed over this class of catalyst, unlike in Cr- and Ga-based catalysts.\nCareful consideration of the nanostructure and composition has shown that the selectivity can be readily tuned to favour different pathways, and further investigation in this area may well be able to harness the high activity of supported nanoparticles as well as favour dehydrogenation pathways.\nDespite dozens of reports over several decades on Cr- and Ga- based catalysts, the improvements in catalyst performance have been incremental.\nThe knowledge gained from these studies on the importance of reducibility and the balance of acid and base sites should be applied to supported NP catalysts, which are a promising and somewhat neglected category of ODH-CO2 catalyst.\nThe specific requirements of catalyst design for each sub-reaction are discussed and we identify that, regardless of the method of dehydrogenation, the balance of acid and base sites on the catalyst surface is of paramount importance.\nThe development of an active, selective and stable catalyst is essential for dehydrogenation to be considered as a viable process in the near- and long-term future.\nIn the case of SC and coal-based MTO, this is unavoidable due to the nature of the feedstock. However, natural gas and propane can be produced from biomass.\nThe increased interest in direct propane dehydrogenation has been enhanced by the fall in propane price, which is the direct result of the discovery of vast shale gas reserves in North America.\nThe production of renewable green propane (also called bio-propane and bioLPG) is an emerging sector which is already being operated on a large scale.\nWith increasing pressure to source chemical feedstocks sustainably, we can expect that new interest will focus on renewable and green routes to the key platform chemicals currently required by modern society, and that green propane will play an important role in this.\nThe majority (86%) of filed patents are for DDH catalysts, followed by ODH-O2 (12%) and finally ODH-CO2 (2.4%).\nThe exact composition of the HGM is likely to include copper oxide and additional promotors such as MnO2, supported on α-Al2O3.\nThe importance of Al speciation in improving catalyst performance and stability was investigated by Shi et al.\nThe modification of Al2O3 with metal oxides, such as TiO2 has been undertaken with some promising results.\nThe role of Cu in the catalyst was to dilute the Pt species and promote desorption of propene, thereby enhancing selectivity.\nThe role of the subsurface was to facilitate the activation of propane on the surface.\nThe irreversible initial deactivation in the consecutive DDH cycles was attributed to either: (i) structural changes of active species (such as agglomeration), or (ii) collapse of pore structure.\nThe positive effect was attributed to the promoters ability to block the sites responsible for coke formation and negligible contribution to undesirable secondary reactions by the additional acid sites generated by the P-based modifier.\nThe authors attributed this enhanced performance to a high dispersion of Cr species, moderate acidity and strong metalsupport interactions in the CrOx/H-ZSM-5(260) catalyst.\nThe authors attributed high Ga/Al ratios (>0.5) with the formation of additional GaxOy clusters which negatively affected the dehydrogenation rate and thus catalytic performance.\nThe activity is dependent on the bond strength of the VOsupport bond. Therefore, it is expected that catalyst performance is affected when different supports, such as SiO2, Al2O3 and ZrO2 are utilised.", "English": "The physicochemical properties of catalysts, including chemical qualities and morphological characteristics, significantly influence their performance in dehydrogenation reactions. The crystallization temperature of the support directly affects the catalytic performance of VOx/Al2O3 catalysts by increasing Lewis acid sites and influencing the distribution of different surface V species. P modification can decrease the degree of VOx polymerization, enhancing catalyst stability and activity. Mg modification can improve catalytic performance and anti-coking capability by dispersing V2O5 crystallites and increasing active V3+ species. Gelation and calcination temperatures also impact the catalytic performance of VOx/SiO2 catalysts in terms of propane conversion, propene selectivity, and yield of propene. Dealuminated beta zeolites (Si-beta) are promising catalyst supports due to their high surface area and thermal stability, and the initial propane conversion linearly increases with the amount of acid sites. VOx/ZrO2 is more active than VOx/Al2O3 and pure ZrO2 due to the facile reduction of VO, VOV, and VOZr bonds, producing higher proportions of the active V3+ species. The balance of acid and base sites on the catalyst surface is crucial for all dehydrogenation methods. The development of an active, selective, and stable catalyst is essential for dehydrogenation to be considered a viable process in the future. Support modification strategies can optimize these properties for enhanced catalytic efficiency and selectivity. Using supports with ordered mesoporosity and moderate surface acidity can aid mass transfer and avoid undesirable secondary reactions. Promoting elements can cause beneficial geometric and electronic effects on both the supports and active species. However, environmental and safety concerns exist in the preparation, usage, and disposal of certain catalysts due to their toxicity. Ga catalysts, while less active than Pt and Cr catalysts, have the advantage of being benign and inexpensive. The nature of the support is essential for vanadium-based catalysts, as the metalsupport interactions affect the resultant catalyst performance. The activity is dependent on the bond strength of the VOsupport bond, and catalyst performance is affected by different supports.", "Chinese": "所有答案结果中的汇总中文答案 1", "Doi": "10.1039/D1GC03700E"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"Although the equilibrium conversion of alkanes increases with temperature, alkene selectivity decreases with increasing temperature and chain length due to an increased tendency toward dehydrocyclization/aromatisation, thermal cracking and coke formation.\"\n          [2] \"The extent of PtSn interactions depends on the impregnation sequence of Pt and Sn precursors on the support material.\"\n          [3] \"The framework of microporous zeolites exerts dispersive forces on the reactant's molecules that depend on the shape, channel and cavity of the framework.\"\n          [4] \"In addition, the nature and the density of the active sites influence the framework dispersion forces.\"\n          [5] \"Recent reports have shown that the strong electrostatic field between protons or exchanged metal ions and basic oxygen species can enhance and/or induce polarization of bonds in hydrocarbon adsorbates.\"\n          [6] \"This agrees with Hashiguchi et al. [26] , who found enhanced activation of the CH bond on a homogeneous catalyst.\"\n          [7] \"Wender et al. [27] showed that 3040% of heat adsorption in n-alkanes on Na-zeolite is due to polarization of the adsorbates.\"\n          [8] \"Subbotina et al. [28] also demonstrated that the CH bond of ethane is more strongly polarized on Mg2 + and Ca2 + forms of Y zeolite than on Na+ forms.\"\n          [9] \"Based on charge density considerations, Mg2 + cations are expected to exhibit a stronger polarizing effect than Ca2 + cations.\"\n          [10] \"Subbotina et al. explain that because of the smaller ionic radius of Mg2 +, it is more strongly shielded by the surrounding oxygen atoms of the zeolite lattice than a Ca2 + ion, thereby reducing the polarizing effect of Mg2 + on the hydrocarbon adsorbate.\"\n          [11] \"Sievers et al. [29] ,[30] also report that the La3 + form of X zeolite induces strong polarization of adsorbed alkane molecules; partial positive charges were induced on secondary and tertiary carbon atoms of alkane molecules.\"\n          [12] \"The authors suggest that the polarization may be viewed as an intermediate condition to hydride abstraction (which is an important elementary step in CH activation).\"\n          [13] \"They add that CH bond polarization was enhanced by physisorbed water molecules that coordinate with La3 + cations.\"\n          [14] \"The enhanced polarization of CH bonds by the presence of water molecules on La3 +X zeolite may have a beneficial effect in oxidative dehydrogenation where water is a by-product.\"\n          [15] \"Alkane polarization studies on Na+, Mg2 +, Ca2 +, and La3 + exchanged X-zeolites indicate that the polarizing effect increases with increasing charge magnitude and ionic radius.\"\n          [16] \"Note that these alkane polarizing cations occupy the same position on the zeolites as the well-known CH activation cations/metals, and thus the CH polarizing effect has a complementary effect on CH activation.\"\n          [17] \"This may add to the number of relevant variables and increase the challenge of optimizing the ratio of activation/polarizing cations among exchangeable sites (Si/Al ratio), as well as the sequence for incorporating the cations or metals during catalyst preparation.\"\n          [18] \"Further, it is important to note that the choice of cations should be such that they exhibit no catalytic (oligomerization, isomerization, aromatisation or oxidation) effects on the target alkene products at the reaction condition.\"\n          [19] \"Furthermore, it may be beneficial to create a CH polarization effect on the zeolite framework.\"\n          [20] \"This can be achieved by appropriate chance of framework atoms.\"\n          [21] \"Since active sites are usually created on the zeolite frameworks.\"\n          [22] \"The active sites (alkoxide intermediate) of the bimolecular pathway are formed in situ ( Scheme 1 ).\"\n          [23] \"The alkoxide intermediate is made up of an alkyl carbenium ion ionically held to the zeolite framework oxygen ion.\"\n          [24] \"The active sites of the unimolecular pathway are the charge balancing protons of the zeolite framework.\"\n          [25] \"A proton and a carbenium ion are an electrophilic or Lewis acid species (a proton can also be considered as a special case of Lewis acidity).\"\n          [26] \"The two pathways essentially involve electrophilic CH activation.\"\n          [27] \"The electrophiles (proton and carbenium ion) activate CH at high temperatures (500 C), giving low conversion rates of light alkanes and poor selectivity to corresponding alkenes.\"\n          [28] \"The elementary steps of CH activation on OGa+ ( Scheme 2 ) reveal that a redox cycle at the metal center is required for catalytic CH activation via the oxidative addition mechanism.\"\n          [29] \"A redox cycle is not apparent in the elementary step presented for CH activation on OZn2+O.\"\n          [30] \"Hence, a redox cycle is not a requisite for CH activation via the Lewis base-assisted deprotonation mechanism.\"\n          [31] \"However, under alkane dehydrogenation reaction conditions, the OZn2+O sites can undergo a reversible Zn2 +/Zn redox process ( Scheme 3 ).\"\n          [32] \"This redox process increases the availability of undesired protonic site intermediates.\"\n          [33] \"Zn-exchanged H-ZSM-5 prepared by conventional ion-exchange methods contain a significant percentage of unexchanged proton sites leading to lower alkene selectivity of the catalyst.\"\n          [34] \"Iglesia and Biscardi [59] titrate the proton sites with NaOH.\"\n          [35] \"The un-titrated and the titrated catalysts are denoted as Zn/H-ZSMS-5 and Zn/Na-ZSMS-5, respectively.\"\n          [36] \"Zn/Na-ZSM-5 has four times the propane conversion rate and a higher propene selectivity than Zn/H-ZSMS-5.\"\n          [37] \"The propene formation rate obtained with Zn/Na-ZSM-5 was ten times that of Zn/H-ZSMS-5.\"\n          [38] \"The zinc species at the cation exchange site of the zeolite was identified as OZn+OH.\"\n          [39] \"The higher propene selectivity obtained on Zn/Na-ZSM-5 compared to Zn/H-ZSM-5 is presumably from the lower density and availability of proton sites on Zn/Na-ZSM-5.\"\n          [40] \"The improved propane conversion rate of Zn/Na-ZSM-5 compared to Zn/H-ZSM-5 is attributable to the higher efficiency of OZn+OH sites in catalyzing desorption of H-adatoms than OZn2+O sites.\"\n          [41] \"Another strategy to enhance alkene selectivity is by controlling the strength of the proton sites.\"\n          [42] \"The acidity of the sites depends on the nature of the trivalent cation of the zeolite framework.\"\n          [43] \"Proton sites in borosilicate zeolites are weaker than those of aluminosilicate [60] ,[61] ,[62] ,[63] ,[64] , and thus higher alkene selectivity is expected for alkane dehydrogenation over Zn/H[B]-ZSM-5 compared to Zn/H[Al]-ZSM-5.\"\n          [44] \"However, Zn/H[B]-ZSM-5 shows no activity for propane dehydrogenation.\"\n          [45] \"The desired weaker acidity of the proton sites of Zn/H[B]-ZSM-5 requires weaker basicity of the oxygen atoms in the zeolite framework.\"\n          [46] \"This reduced basicity of the oxygen atoms is not sufficiently polarizing to complement the exchanged Zn2 + in CH bond cleavage.\"\n          [47] \"In the next section, we examine use of zeolite support to design a Pt-based alkane dehydrogenation catalyst.\"\n          [48] \"Elimination of the proton sites of zeolites is critical for obtaining a high alkene selectivity and stability in dehydrogenation catalysts.\"\n          [49] \"Pt is the most versatile noble metal catalyst for alkane reactions [65] .\"\n          [50] \"Although Pt is expensive, the choice of Pt is often justified by its higher activity, stability and selectivity for these reactions compared to less expensive alternative transition metals.\"\n          [51] \"However, rapid catalyst deactivation due to coke formation remains a challenge even when using a Pt-based catalyst for dehydrogenation of light alkanes.\"\n          [52] \"Waku et al. [66] exploited the unique property of zeolite as a support for achieving high metal dispersion through cation exchange sites to create a Pt/Na[Fe]-ZSM-5 catalyst with outstanding stability for dehydrogenation of light alkanes.\"\n          [53] \"They found that the catalyst deactivation rate of Pt/Na[Fe]-ZSM-5 was lower than for any other Pt-based catalysts in refractory oxide support.\"\n          [54] \"The unprecedented performance of Pt/Na[Fe]-ZSM-5 was attributed to its high Pt dispersion (cluster size < 1 mm) on zeolite through ion-exchange.\"\n          [55] \"There is a tendency to generate some Brnsted protons on the zeolite during the exchange process, but the choice of Fe3 + as an isomorphous cation in place of Al3 + led to weaker Brnsted sites in [Fe]-ZSM compared to [Al]-ZSM.\"\n          [56] \"The weaker acidity minimizes the tendency of side reactions (cracking of oligomerization, aromatisation, and coke), which translates into higher alkene selectivity and catalyst stability.\"\n          [57] \"In another report, Xuebing and Iglesia [67] demonstrated the ability of Pt/Na[Fe]-ZSM-5 to dehydrogenate alkanes longer than C4; n-pentane and n-heptane were selectively converted to n-pentene and n-heptene, respectively.\"\n          [58] \"Alkene selectivity was also improved when the residual proton generated during Pt exchange or Na-[Fe]-ZSM was titrated with Cs [67] .\"\n          [59] \"Although Pt with conventional refractory oxides (Al2O3, SiO2, ZrO2, etc.) used for dehydrogenation of alkanes has similar conversion rates to Pt/Na[Fe]-ZSM-5, deactivation rates are also rapid due to coke formation.\"\n          [60] \"The presence of acid (Bronsted and Lewis) sites on the supports promotes readsorption, oligomerization and aromatisation of alkenes.\"\n          [61] \"Promotion of Pt with metals, such as Sn, Ga, Zn, Re, etc., improves catalyst stability, but also leads to faster deactivation rates than Pt/Na[Fe]-ZSM-5.\"\n          [62] \"However, recent reports by Bell et al. [68] ,[69] ,[70] show that the use of calcined hydrotalcite (Al/Mg  0.1) supported on bimetallic PtGa or PtSn gave very high alkene selectivity and stability, comparable to Pt/Na[Fe]-ZSM-5.\"\n          [63] \"At this stage, we can conclude that differences in the performance of Zn and Ga exchanged H-ZSM-5 obtained by Kanansky et al. [53] are attributable to their respective CH activation mechanisms.\"\n          [64] \"In addition, the role of exchanged Zn and Ga as promoters of RD becomes evident from the mechanisms ( Scheme 2 ).\"\n          [65] \"The RD mechanism on Ga exchanged H-ZSM-5 is by reductive elimination of a hydrogen molecule from O[Ga(H)2]+ intermediate.\"\n          [66] \"Decomposition of ZnR and a protonic site, or neutralization of the proton sites by ZnH, leads to desorption of the hydrogen molecule on the Zn-exchanged H-ZSM-5.\"\n          [67] \"By extrapolation, the mechanisms of CH activation on exchanged Zn and Ga H-ZSM-5 can described the mechanism of alkane dehydrogenation on Cr-based and Pt-based catalysts respectively.\"\n          [68] \"The electronic promotion effect of Sn is in line with the oxidative addition CH activation mechanism.\"\n          [69] \"However, the Lewis base-assisted deprotonation mechanism could also explain the proposed CH activation on Cr-based catalysts.\"\n          [70] \"Now, the nature and the role of surface oxygen species become more evident.\"\n          [71] \"The role of potassium in commercial Cr and Pt-based dehydrogenation catalysts is to minimize the undesired influence of protonic sites on alkene selectivity.\"\n          [72] \"The highlights in this section are presented in Table 2 .\"\n          [73] \"The table reveals the insights achieved on the reaction mechanism, alkene selectivity and catalyst stability for non-oxidative dehydrogenation of lower alkanes.\"\n          [74] \"Nonetheless, the level of catalyst activity is still far from acceptable, even at high temperature.\"\n          [75] \"A recent report by Rothenberg et al. [71] provides a lead in this respect.\"\n          [76] \"Their report indicates that a porous copperaluminum framework material (stabilized by metal oxide) has better performance (activity/selectivity/stability) for propane dehydrogenation than a PtSn/Al2O3.\"\n          [77] \"Of particular interest, is the suggestion that achieving propane dehydrogenation at 350 C may be possible.\"\n          [78] \"Few details are known about the structure of the porous copperaluminum framework material.\"\n          [79] \"However, copper is implicated as providing the active sites for the catalysis.\"\n          [80] \"Also, that the material activated in oxygen gave higher propane conversion rates than those activated in inert gas atmosphere underscores the role of the surface oxide (oxygen species) in the catalysis.\"\n          [81] \"Thus, the Lewis base-assisted deprotonation mechanism may be invoked here, and the redox property of the metal center is likely to play a role in achieving propane dehydrogenation at 350 C.\"\n          [82] \"This should constitute the future research direction for non-oxidative dehydrogenation of lower alkanes.\"", "English": "The physicochemical properties of catalysts, including chemical qualities (such as acid strength and stability) and morphological characteristics, significantly influence their performance in dehydrogenation reactions. The equilibrium conversion of alkanes increases with temperature, but alkene selectivity decreases due to an increased tendency toward dehydrocyclization/aromatisation, thermal cracking, and coke formation. The extent of PtSn interactions depends on the impregnation sequence of Pt and Sn precursors on the support material. The framework of microporous zeolites exerts dispersive forces on reactant molecules, which depend on the shape, channel, and cavity of the framework. The nature and density of active sites also influence the framework dispersion forces. Recent reports have shown that the strong electrostatic field between protons or exchanged metal ions and basic oxygen species can enhance and/or induce polarization of bonds in hydrocarbon adsorbates. This polarization effect can be viewed as an intermediate condition to hydride abstraction, an important elementary step in CH activation. The polarizing effect increases with increasing charge magnitude and ionic radius of the alkane polarizing cations. The choice of cations should be such that they exhibit no catalytic effects on the target alkene products at the reaction condition. It may be beneficial to create a CH polarization effect on the zeolite framework by appropriate modification of framework atoms. Active sites are usually created on the zeolite frameworks. The active sites of the bimolecular pathway are formed in situ and are made up of an alkyl carbenium ion ionically held to the zeolite framework oxygen ion. The active sites of the unimolecular pathway are the charge balancing protons of the zeolite framework. A proton and a carbenium ion are electrophilic or Lewis acid species, and the two pathways essentially involve electrophilic CH activation. The exchanged metal ions in zeolites are held ionically by one or more basic oxygen atoms. Different species have been suggested, depending on the density of the cation exchange site of the zeolite and the method of introduction of the metals. High alkene selectivities are obtained on the H-ZSM-5 when exchangeable protons are rigorously replaced by Zn and Ga. The CH activation on the OZn2+O site can be described by a Lewis base-assisted deprotonation mechanism, accompanied by conversion of the Lewis base site to a conjugate Bronsted acid site. The OGa+ site, however, activates the CH bond via oxidative addition without a protonic site intermediate. A protonic site intermediate increases the tendency of side reactions on the Zn-exchanged H-ZSM-5 relative to the Ga counterpart. The elementary steps of CH activation on OGa+ reveal that a redox cycle at the metal center is required for catalytic CH activation via the oxidative addition mechanism. However, under alkane dehydrogenation reaction conditions, the OZn2+O sites can undergo a reversible Zn2+/Zn redox process, increasing the availability of undesired protonic site intermediates. Zn-exchanged H-ZSM-5 prepared by conventional ion-exchange methods contain a significant percentage of unexchanged proton sites, leading to lower alkene selectivity of the catalyst. Another strategy to enhance alkene selectivity is by controlling the strength of the proton sites. The acidity of the sites depends on the nature of the trivalent cation of the zeolite framework. Proton sites in borosilicate zeolites are weaker than those of aluminosilicate, and thus higher alkene selectivity is expected for alkane dehydrogenation over Zn/H[B]-ZSM-5 compared to Zn/H[Al]-ZSM-5. However, Zn/H[B]-ZSM-5 shows no activity for propane dehydrogenation. The desired weaker acidity of the proton sites of Zn/H[B]-ZSM-5 requires weaker basicity of the oxygen atoms in the zeolite framework. This reduced basicity of the oxygen atoms is not sufficiently polarizing to complement the exchanged Zn2+ in CH bond cleavage. Elimination of the proton sites of zeolites is critical for obtaining a high alkene selectivity and stability in dehydrogenation catalysts. Pt is the most versatile noble metal catalyst for alkane reactions, often justified by its higher activity, stability, and selectivity for these reactions compared to less expensive alternative transition metals. However, rapid catalyst deactivation due to coke formation remains a challenge even when using a Pt-based catalyst for dehydrogenation of light alkanes. The presence of acid (Bronsted and Lewis) sites on the supports promotes readsorption, oligomerization, and aromatization of alkenes. Promotion of Pt with metals, such as Sn, Ga, Zn, Re, etc., improves catalyst stability, but also leads to faster deactivation rates than Pt/Na[Fe]-ZSM-5. The role of potassium in commercial Cr and Pt-based dehydrogenation catalysts is to minimize the undesired influence of protonic sites on alkene selectivity. The nature and role of surface oxygen species become more evident. The electronic promotion effect of Sn is in line with the oxidative addition CH activation mechanism. However, the Lewis base-assisted deprotonation mechanism could also explain the proposed CH activation on Cr-based catalysts. A recent report suggests that a porous copper-aluminum framework material (stabilized by metal oxide) has better performance (activity/selectivity/stability) for propane dehydrogenation than a PtSn/Al2O3. The Lewis base-assisted deprotonation mechanism may be invoked here, and the redox property of the metal center is likely to play a role in achieving propane dehydrogenation at 350 C. This should constitute the future research direction for non-oxidative dehydrogenation of lower alkanes.", "Chinese": "催化剂的物理化学性质，包括化学品质（如酸强度和稳定性）和形态特征，对脱氢反应的性能有重大影响。随着温度的升高，烷烃的平衡转化率增加，但由于脱氢环化/芳构化、热裂解和焦炭形成的倾向增加，烯烃的选择性降低。PtSn相互作用的程度取决于Pt和Sn前体在支撑材料上的浸渍顺序。微孔沸石框架对反应物分子施加的分散力取决于框架的形状、通道和腔体。活性位点的性质和密度也影响框架的分散力。最近的报告表明，质子或交换金属离子与基本氧物种之间的强静电场可以增强和/或诱导烃吸附物中键的极化。这种极化效应可以视为向氢化物抽离过渡的中间条件，这是CH活化的重要基本步骤。极化效应随电荷大小和离子半径的增加而增加。选择的阳离子应确保在反应条件下对目标烯烃产品没有催化作用。在沸石框架上创造CH极化效应可能是有益的，这可以通过适当修改框架原子来实现。活性位点通常在沸石框架上创建。双分子途径的活性位点是原位形成的，由离子结合到沸石框架氧离子的烷基卡宾离子组成。单分子途径的活性位点是沸石框架的质子平衡电荷。质子和卡宾离子是亲电性或路易斯酸性物种，两种途径本质上涉及亲电性CH活化。沸石中交换的金属离子通过一个或多个基本氧原子离子结合。根据沸石的阳离子交换位点密度和金属的引入方法，提出了不同的物种。当可交换的质子被严格替换为Zn和Ga时，H-ZSM-5获得了高烯烃选择性。OZn2+O位点上的CH活化可以通过路易斯碱辅助脱质子机制来描述，伴随路易斯碱位点转化为共轭布龙斯特酸位点。然而，OGa+位点通过氧化加成而不是质子位点中间体活化CH键。质子位点中间体增加了Zn交换的H-ZSM-5相对于Ga对应物的副反应倾向。OGa+的CH活化基本步骤揭示，金属中心的氧化还原循环是通过氧化加成机制催化CH活化所必需的。然而，在烷烃脱氢反应条件下，OZn2+O位点可以经历可逆的Zn2+/Zn氧化还原过程，增加了不希望的质子位点中间体的可用性。通过传统离子交换方法制备的Zn交换H-ZSM-5含有大量未交换的质子位点，导致催化剂的烯烃选择性降低。另一种增强烯烃选择性的策略是控制质子位点的强度。位点的酸性取决于沸石框架中三价阳离子的性质。硼硅酸盐沸石中的质子位点比铝硅酸盐弱，因此预计Zn/H[B]-ZSM-5在烷烃脱氢中的烯烃选择性高于Zn/H[Al]-ZSM-5。然而，Zn/H[B]-ZSM-5在丙烷脱氢中没有活性。Zn/H[B]-ZSM-5中所需较弱的质子位点酸性需要沸石框架中氧原子的较弱碱性。这种氧原子碱性的降低不足以补充交换的Zn2+在CH键断裂中的作用。消除沸石的质子位点对于获得高烯烃选择性和脱氢催化剂的稳定性至关重要。Pt是烷烃反应中最通用的贵金属催化剂，通常因其在这些反应中的较高活性、稳定性和选择性而被证明是合理的，与成本较低的替代过渡金属相比。然而，即使使用Pt基催化剂进行轻烷烃脱氢，由于焦炭形成导致的催化剂失活速度仍然很快。支持物上的酸（布龙斯特和路易斯）位点促进了烯烃的再吸附、寡聚化和芳构化。Pt与Sn、Ga、Zn、Re等金属的促进提高了催化剂的稳定性，但与Pt/Na[Fe]-ZSM-5相比，失活速度也更快。商业Cr和Pt基脱氢催化剂中钾的作用是最大限度地减少质子位点对烯烃选择性的不利影响。表面氧物种的性质和作用变得更加明显。Sn的电子促进效应与氧化加成CH活化机制一致。然而，路易斯碱辅助脱质子机制也可以解释在Cr基催化剂上提出的CH活化。最近的一份报告表明，一种多孔铜铝框架材料（由金属氧化物稳定）在丙烷脱氢中的性能（活性/选择性/稳定性）优于PtSn/Al2O3。可以在此处调用路易斯碱辅助脱质子机制，金属中心的氧化还原性质可能在实现350°C下的丙烷脱氢中发挥作用。这应该是非氧化脱氢较低烷烃的未来研究方向。", "Doi": "10.1016/j.fuproc.2016.04.016"},
{"Quotes": "[3] \"The robustness against coking can be increased with additional promoters, such as late transition metals, main-group metals including Sn and Ga, alkali-metal oxides and rare-earth metal oxides.\"\n          [4] \"The existence of Au atoms shifts down the d band of alloys, which weakens the interaction between σ* of CH bond and d states of surface metal atoms. Thus, the transition state gains less stabilization from surface atoms, and finally results in an increase of the dissociation barrier height.\"\n          [5] \"The lower reactivity (i.e. higher dehydrogenation barrier) on PtSn alloy is due to the deeper d-band center compared to pure Pt.\"\n          [6] \"The PtCu catalyst inhibits the adsorption of formed propylene, and thus suppresses the secondary cracking reactions from propylene towards lighter hydrocarbons. Thus, this reduced interaction between the product and the catalysts enhances the anti-coking ability of the catalyst.\"\n          [7] \"The stability of metal oxides or hydride clusters is also influenced by the structure of the zeolite framework.\"\n          [8] \"The pore size is also considered to have a slight effect on the catalytic activity, i.e., lower activation barriers for reactions in zeolites with larger pore size.\"\n          [9] \"The weak binding of the intermediate on such sites favors the desorption of H2. Considering these two opposite effects, calculations suggested that the optimal AlAl distance to be 453 pm corresponding to a minimum overall barrier, and a simple structure-to-activity correlation based on the Sabatier principle was proposed.\"\n          [10] \"The ultimate goal for theoretical studies is to identify optimal catalysts for particular chemical processes.\"\n          [11] \"The continuing improvements of computer hardware, the development of new functionals, as well as the increasing sophistication of computational electronic structure software have insured the ability of a computational study to access more complicated catalytic systems beyond simple transition-metal surfaces.\"\n          [12] \"Although the general trend of catalytic activity is not as easy to be addressed for these as for metal systems, the case studies still shed light on dehydrogenation mechanisms in these systems, and more insights emerge which are normally difficult to be explored at molecular level even by the most advanced experimental equipment.\"\n          [13] \"The robustness against coking can be increased with additional promoters, such as late transition metals, main-group metals including Sn and Ga, alkali-metal oxides and rare-earth metal oxides.\"\n          [14] \"The existence of Au atoms shifts down the d band of alloys, which weakens the interaction between σ* of CH bond and d states of surface metal atoms. Thus, the transition state gains less stabilization from surface atoms, and finally results in an increase of the dissociation barrier height.\"\n          [15] \"The lower reactivity (i.e. higher dehydrogenation barrier) on PtSn alloy is due to the deeper d-band center compared to pure Pt.\"\n          [16] \"The PtCu catalyst inhibits the adsorption of formed propylene, and thus suppresses the secondary cracking reactions from propylene towards lighter hydrocarbons. Thus, this reduced interaction between the product and the catalysts enhances the anti-coking ability of the catalyst.\"\n          [17] \"The stability of metal oxides or hydride clusters is also influenced by the structure of the zeolite framework.\"\n          [18] \"The weak binding of the intermediate on such sites favors the desorption of H2. Considering these two opposite effects, calculations suggested that the optimal AlAl distance to be 453 pm corresponding to a minimum overall barrier, and a simple structure-to-activity correlation based on the Sabatier principle was proposed.\"\n          [19] \"The ultimate goal for theoretical studies is to identify optimal catalysts for particular chemical processes.\"\n          [20] \"The continuing improvements of computer hardware, the development of new functionals, as well as the increasing sophistication of computational electronic structure software have insured the ability of a computational study to access more complicated catalytic systems beyond simple transition-metal surfaces.\"\n          [21] \"The lattice mismatch between the particle and support results in a shift of relative positions between sites on particle and surface, which results in different environments of given sites, leading to a large number of possibilities to be considered in a single study.\"\n          [22] \"The complexity of the systems mentioned above seems to beyond the ability to completely scan the potential energy surfaces to a large extent with DFT calculations, which limits most of the current studies which focus to understand one aspect of the catalyst instead of the complete picture of dehydrogenation.\"", "English": "The physicochemical properties of catalysts, including chemical qualities (such as acid strength and stability) and morphological characteristics, significantly influence their performance in dehydrogenation reactions. For instance, the stability of metal oxides or hydride clusters is influenced by the structure of the zeolite framework, and the pore size of zeolites has a slight effect on the catalytic activity, with lower activation barriers for reactions in zeolites with larger pore size. The optimal distance between active sites, such as AlAl distance in zeolites, can be determined to achieve a minimum overall barrier, based on the Sabatier principle. The ultimate goal of theoretical studies is to identify optimal catalysts for specific chemical processes, and the advancements in computational approaches have enabled the exploration of more complex catalytic systems beyond simple transition-metal surfaces. Case studies have provided insights into dehydrogenation mechanisms in these systems, revealing information that is challenging to obtain at the molecular level even with advanced experimental equipment.", "Chinese": "催化剂的物理化学性质，包括化学品质（如酸强度和稳定性）和形态特征，对脱氢反应的性能有重大影响。例如，金属氧化物或氢化物簇的稳定性受沸石框架结构的影响，沸石的孔径大小对催化活性有轻微影响，孔径较大的沸石反应的活化能较低。沸石中活性位点（如AlAl距离）的最优距离可以根据萨巴蒂尔原理确定，以达到最小的整体能垒。理论研究的最终目标是为特定化学过程识别最优催化剂，计算方法的进步使我们能够探索比简单过渡金属表面更复杂的催化系统。案例研究为这些系统中的脱氢机制提供了见解，揭示了即使是使用最先进的实验设备也难以在分子水平上获得的信息。", "Doi": "10.1039/C5SC01227A"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"PtGaCaPb/SiO2 exhibited outstanding catalytic stability in PDH at 600C, and almost no deactivation was observed for up to 1month.\"\n          [2] \"The geometric and electronic effects are known to be pivotal to most catalytic systems, including the PDH one.\"\n          [3] \"Pb is deposited on the three-fold Pt3 sites of the PtGa nanoparticles to block them, whereas Ca, which affords an electron-enriched single-atom-like Pt1 site, is placed around the nanoparticles.\"\n          [4] \"Thus, PtGaCaPb/SiO2 exhibits an outstandingly high catalytic stability, even at 600C (kd=0.00033h1, τ=3067h), and almost no deactivation of the catalyst was observed for up to 1month for the first time.\"\n          [5] \"The ensemble effect can also be maximized by completely isolating the Pt atoms by the second metals, thus favoring the first and second CH scissions, whereas the subsequent CH scission would be successfully inhibited.\"\n          [6] \"Hence, tuning the electronic properties of Pt can be another approach for increasing the lifetime of PDH catalysts.\"\n          [7] \"Therefore, the double modification of PtGa to synergize the geometric and electronic promotion effects can be a promising catalyst design concept to construct an ultra-stable catalytic system for PDH.\"\n          [8] \"The surface of the intermetallic PtGa nanoparticles on SiO2 was decorated with Pb for the geometric modification to block the Pt3 sites.\"\n          [9] \"Moreover, a certain alkali or alkaline earth cation, such as Ca2+,26-28 is deposited around the PtGa nanoparticles as an electron-donating agent.\"\n          [10] \"The resulting electron-enriched Pt1 site is expected to function as an ideal active site that can almost perfectly suppress side reactions in PDH.\"", "English": "The physicochemical properties of catalysts, including chemical qualities and morphological characteristics, significantly influence their performance in dehydrogenation reactions. The geometric and electronic effects are crucial to catalytic systems, particularly in propane dehydrogenation (PDH). The double decoration of PtGa intermetallics with Pb and Ca is a promising catalyst design concept that synergizes the geometric and electronic promotion effects, leading to an ultra-stable catalytic system for PDH. Pb is used for geometric modification to block Pt3 sites, while Ca acts as an electron-donating agent to enrich the electron density of Pt1 sites, suppressing side reactions. This strategy results in a catalyst with outstanding stability in PDH for up to 1 month at 600C.", "Chinese": "催化剂的物理化学性质，包括化学品质和形态特征，对脱氢反应的性能有重大影响。几何和电子效应对于催化系统至关重要，特别是在丙烷脱氢（PDH）中。PtGa金属间化合物的双重装饰与Pb和Ca是很有前景的催化剂设计概念，它协同了几何和电子促进效应，导致PDH的超稳定催化系统。Pb用于几何修饰以阻塞Pt3位点，而Ca作为电子供体，增加Pt1位点的电子密度，抑制副反应。这种策略导致在600C下PDH长达1个月的稳定性。", "Doi": "10.1002/anie.202107210"},
{"Quotes": "", "English": "The literature does not provide specific information on how physicochemical properties of catalysts influence their performance in dehydrogenation reactions or on support modification strategies to optimize these properties. However, it does discuss the influence of support acidity on the electronic properties of supported metals, and how the presence of metals affects the acidic properties of supports. The study shows that the electronic properties of Pt are influenced by the acidity of the support, and the alteration of Pt properties increases with increasing acidity of the support. At the same time, the presence of platinum affects the acidic properties of the supports by reducing the strength of the acid sites. This is observed directly as the changes in desorption of pyridine from the acid sites and indirectly as the suppression of cracking reactions during the ring opening of decalin on the Pt-modified catalysts. This could potentially impact the catalytic efficiency and selectivity in reactions that require both metal and acid active sites.", "Chinese": "文献没有提供催化剂的物理化学性质如何影响其在脱氢反应中的性能，或支持修改策略以优化这些性质的具体信息。但是，它确实讨论了支持酸性对支持金属的电子性质的影响，以及金属的存在如何影响支持的酸性性质。研究显示，Pt的电子性质受支持酸性的影响，且Pt性质的改变随支持酸性的增加而增加。同时，铂的存在通过降低酸位点的强度影响支持的酸性性质。这直接表现为从酸位点脱附的吡啶的变化，间接表现为在Pt改性催化剂上脱氢反应中裂解反应的抑制。这可能会影响在需要金属和酸活性位点的反应中的催化效率和选择性。", "Doi": "10.1021/jp055754k"},
{"Quotes": "Al2O3 is one of the most commonly used supports in heterogeneous catalysis due to its structural advantages and stability.\n          The coordinately unsaturated Al3+ sites present on the (100) facets of commercial γ-Al2O3 can serve as anchor sites to anchor atomically dispersed Pt and Ru sites.\n          The specific interaction between Ga2O3 and Al2O3 can allow the tetrahedral Ga3+ cations to highly disperse in the spinel-type γ-Ga2O3-Al2O3 solid solution, leading to an enhanced activity and stability in PDH reaction.\n          The γ-Al2O3 nanosheet containing 27% penta-coordinated Al3+ sites has been proved that it could nicely disperse and stabilize bimetallic PtSn nanoclusters because of the strong interactions between metals and support.\n          This PtSn/Al2O3 sheet catalyst displayed an excellent performance at an ultrahigh space velocity in a long-term PDH reaction.\n          In addition to being an appropriate support, the hydroxyl groups-eliminated Al2O3 showed a high activity of coordinately unsaturated Al3+ as the surface active sites in non-oxidative dehydrogenation of isobutane to isobutylene.\n          Furthermore, the diversity and complexity on the structure of Al2O3, for example the surface acidity at the low-coordinated Al sites, determined the different properties in the adsorption and the activation of propane as well as coke deposition in the PDH reaction.\n          Herein, a one-step hydrothermal method is employed to synthesize sheet-shaped CoAl2O3HT catalysts for efficiently catalyzing the PDH reaction.\n          The structural and catalytic stabilities as well as the CoAl2O3 interaction for these catalysts are benchmarked to an impregnated Co/Al2O3-IMP catalyst.\n          We further illustrate the effect of C3H6 desorption behavior in the Co-catalyzed PDH reaction.", "English": "The physicochemical properties of catalysts, including chemical qualities and morphological characteristics, significantly influence their performance in dehydrogenation reactions. Al2O3, due to its structural advantages and stability, is commonly used as a support in heterogeneous catalysis. The coordinately unsaturated Al3+ sites on the (100) facets of commercial γ-Al2O3 can serve as anchor sites for atomically dispersed Pt and Ru sites. The specific interaction between Ga2O3 and Al2O3 allows the tetrahedral Ga3+ cations to disperse in the spinel-type γ-Ga2O3-Al2O3 solid solution, enhancing activity and stability in PDH reactions. The γ-Al2O3 nanosheet, containing 27% penta-coordinated Al3+ sites, can disperse and stabilize bimetallic PtSn nanoclusters due to strong interactions between metals and support, leading to excellent performance in long-term PDH reactions at ultrahigh space velocities. Hydroxyl groups-eliminated Al2O3 shows high activity of coordinately unsaturated Al3+ as surface active sites in non-oxidative dehydrogenation of isobutane to isobutylene. The diversity and complexity of Al2O3 structure, such as surface acidity at low-coordinated Al sites, determine different properties in propane adsorption, activation, and coke deposition in PDH reactions. A one-step hydrothermal method synthesizes sheet-shaped CoAl2O3HT catalysts for efficient PDH catalysis, benchmarking structural and catalytic stabilities and CoAl2O3 interactions against an impregnated Co/Al2O3-IMP catalyst. The effect of C3H6 desorption behavior in Co-catalyzed PDH reactions is further illustrated. Support modification strategies, such as the use of γ-Al2O3 nanosheets and the specific interaction between Ga2O3 and Al2O3, can optimize these properties for enhanced catalytic efficiency and selectivity.", "Chinese": "催化剂的物理化学性质，包括化学品质和形态特征，对脱氢反应的性能有重大影响。Al2O3作为异相催化中常用的载体，提供了结构优势和稳定性。商业γ-Al2O3的(100)面上的配位不饱和Al3+位点可以作为锚定位点，锚定原子分散的Pt和Ru位点。Ga2O3和Al2O3之间的特定相互作用允许四面体Ga3+阳离子在尖晶石型γ-Ga2O3-Al2O3固溶体中高度分散，提高了PDH反应的活性和稳定性。含有27%五配位Al3+位点的γ-Al2O3纳米片可以分散和稳定双金属PtSn纳米团簇，因为金属和载体之间有强烈的相互作用，这在长期PDH反应中以超高空间速度表现出优异的性能。去除羟基的Al2O3显示出高活性的配位不饱和Al3+作为表面活性位点，在异丁烷非氧化脱氢为异丁烯中表现出高活性。Al2O3结构的多样性和复杂性，例如低配位Al位点的表面酸性，决定了丙烷的吸附和活化以及PDH反应中焦炭沉积的不同性质。采用一步水热法合成片状CoAl2O3HT催化剂，用于高效催化PDH反应，与浸渍的Co/Al2O3-IMP催化剂相比，基准结构和催化稳定性以及CoAl2O3相互作用。进一步说明了C3H6脱附行为在Co催化PDH反应中的影响。支撑改性策略，如使用γ-Al2O3纳米片和Ga2O3与Al2O3之间的特定相互作用，可以优化这些性质，以增强催化效率和选择性。", "Doi": "10.1016/j.jcat.2019.11.026"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The acidity of Si-Beta, 0.1Pt/Si-Beta, 2Zn/Si-Beta and 0.1Pt-2Zn/Si-Beta samples were evaluated by means of NH3-TPD and the results are shown in Fig. 3 (c). Parent H-Beta demonstrates two NH3 desorption peaks, revealing the presence of both weak and strong acid sites, respectively (not shown here) [37] ,[38] ,[39] ,[40] ,[41] . After the complete dealumination of H-Beta, no desorption peaks could be observed for the resulting Si-Beta sample due to the absence of acid sites [42] . Subsequently, the introduction of a small amount of Pt species to the Si-Beta support results in the appearance of trace medium acid sites (NH3 desorption peak centered at 523 K) and the introduction of Zn results in the appearance of higher amount of Lewis acid sites (NH3 desorption peak centered at 423 K). With the introduction of Pt into 2Zn/Si-Beta, an ammonia desorption peak centered at 443 K with much higher intensity could be observed on 0.1Pt-2Zn/Si-Beta. With electrons transfer from Zn species to Pt species, the Zn species become electron-deficient and Lewis acidic thereof. In other word, the observed Lewis acidity in 0.1Pt-2Zn/Si-Beta as compared to 2Zn/Si-Beta should indicate the strong interaction between Pt and Zn species on the Si-Beta support.\"\n          [2] \"The morphology of the zeolite support and the dispersion of Pt and Zn species on Si-Beta support were directly investigated by electron microscopy and the representative results are shown in Fig. 2 . Generally, 0.1Pt-2Zn/Si-Beta appears as small aggregates of below 100 nm. In the HR-TEM image, homogeneously dispersed dark dots of 1  2.5 nm could be observed. STEM mapping analyses reveal the presence of both highly-dispersed Zn species (<1 nm) and small aggregates (1  2.5 nm). Meanwhile, no aggregation of Pt species could be observed due to its high dispersion and low loading. Obviously, Pt and Zn species appear in the overlapped locations, hinting to the close contact between Pt and Zn species on Si-Beta zeolite support.\"\n          [3] \"The evolution the silanol groups after dealumination and metal incorporation procedures was monitored by infrared spectroscopy to disclosed the formation of Pt-Zn species on Si-Beta zeolite.\"\n          [4] \"The local electronic environment of Pt is of great significance for PDH process. In this study, the local electronic environment of Pt was investigated by FTIR spectra of CO adsorption, which is reliable for the discrimination of highly dispersed Pt centers and large metal bulks even at very low Pt loading.\"\n          [5] \"The XRD patterns of the parent H-Beta, Si-Beta, Zn/Si-Beta, and Pt-Zn/Si-Beta are shown in Fig. 1 (a). Typical diffraction lines characteristic for the BEA topology are observed for all samples, while a noticeable decline in the intensity could be observed after the introduction of Zn species.\"\n          [6] \"The surface areas of zeolite samples were determined by argon adsorption/desorption isotherms at 87 K collected on a Quantachrome iQ-MP gas adsorption analyzer. The Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET) method was used to calculate the total surface area and the t-plot method was employed to calculate the micropore properties.\"\n          [7] \"The detailed textural properties of Si-Beta, and M/Si-Beta samples are summarized in Table S1 . All samples exhibit similar high surface areas of 553  616 m2 g1 and large micropore volumes of 0.3510.413 cm3 g1, indicating the well preserved microporous structure of Beta zeolite after dealumination and metal incorporation.\"\n          [8] \"The introduction of Pt species via impregnation does not change the dispersion of Zn species on Si-Beta support.\"\n          [9] \"The close contact between Pt-Zn species and the electronic interaction thereof make Pt-Zn/Si-Beta robust PDH catalysts.\"", "English": "The acidity of the catalysts was evaluated by NH3-TPD, revealing that parent H-Beta has both weak and strong acid sites, while Si-Beta lacks acid sites after dealumination. The introduction of Pt species results in trace medium acid sites, and Zn species introduce higher amounts of Lewis acid sites. The presence of Pt in 2Zn/Si-Beta leads to an ammonia desorption peak with much higher intensity, indicating strong interaction between Pt and Zn species. Electron microscopy shows that 0.1Pt-2Zn/Si-Beta appears as small aggregates below 100 nm, with Pt and Zn species having close contact on the Si-Beta support. Infrared spectroscopy monitored the evolution of silanol groups after dealumination and metal incorporation, revealing the formation of Pt-Zn species on Si-Beta zeolite. The local electronic environment of Pt is significant for the PDH process and was investigated by FTIR spectra of CO adsorption. XRD patterns show typical diffraction lines for the BEA topology, with a decline in intensity after Zn introduction. Surface areas of zeolite samples were determined by argon adsorption/desorption isotherms, revealing high surface areas and large micropore volumes for all samples, indicating well-preserved microporous structures after dealumination and metal incorporation. The introduction of Pt species via impregnation does not change the dispersion of Zn species on Si-Beta support. The close contact between Pt-Zn species and the electronic interaction thereof make Pt-Zn/Si-Beta robust PDH catalysts.", "Chinese": "通过NH3-TPD评估了催化剂的酸性，揭示了母体H-Beta具有弱酸性和强酸性位点，而Si-Beta在脱铝后没有酸性位点。引入Pt物种导致微量中等酸性位点的出现，而Zn物种引入更高量的Lewis酸性位点。2Zn/Si-Beta中Pt的存在导致氨脱附峰的强度大大增加，表明Pt和Zn物种之间存在强烈的相互作用。电子显微镜显示0.1Pt-2Zn/Si-Beta表现为小于100纳米的小聚集体，Pt和Zn物种在Si-Beta支撑上具有紧密的接触。红外光谱监测了脱铝和金属掺入后硅醇基团的演变，揭示了Si-Beta沸石上Pt-Zn物种的形成。Pt的局部电子环境对PDH过程具有重要意义，并通过CO吸附的FTIR光谱进行了研究。XRD图案显示了BEA拓扑结构的典型衍射线，引入Zn物种后强度下降。通过87K的氩气吸附/脱附等温线确定了沸石样品的表面积，所有样品均显示出高表面积和大微孔体积，表明脱铝和金属掺入后Beta沸石的微孔结构得到了很好的保留。通过浸渍引入Pt物种不会改变Zn物种在Si-Beta支撑上的分散。Pt-Zn物种之间的紧密接触和电子相互作用使Pt-Zn/Si-Beta成为PDH催化剂的稳健选择。", "Doi": "10.1016/j.jechem.2020.08.058"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"NaCl excess contributes to stability of propane dehydrogenation MFI-zeolite catalysts.\"\n          [2] \"NaCl promotes Pt dispersion, prevents sintering during calcination, and effectively suppresses zeolite acidity.\"\n          [3] \"Washing after the calcination of Pt-containing catalysts further increases the catalyst activity and stability due to the redispersion of water-soluble chlorinated Pt compounds.\"\n          [4] \"High external surface acid site concentrations, Na/Pt atomic ratios of 4070, calcination temperatures of 400500 C, washing with water, and the order of component introduction when the excess NaCl and the precursor of Pt are calcined jointly contribute to improved Pt dispersion and catalyst stability.\"", "English": "The physicochemical properties of catalysts, including chemical qualities and morphological characteristics, significantly influence their performance in dehydrogenation reactions. The addition of excess NaCl contributes to the stability of propane dehydrogenation MFI-zeolite catalysts. NaCl promotes the dispersion of Pt, prevents sintering during calcination, and effectively suppresses zeolite acidity. Washing the catalysts after calcination further increases their activity and stability due to the redispersion of water-soluble chlorinated Pt compounds. High external surface acid site concentrations, specific Na/Pt atomic ratios, calcination temperatures, washing with water, and the order of component introduction all contribute to improved Pt dispersion and catalyst stability.", "Chinese": "催化剂的物理化学性质，包括化学品质和形态特征，对脱氢反应的性能有重大影响。过量的NaCl有助于丙烷脱氢MFI-沸石催化剂的稳定性。NaCl促进Pt的分散，防止煅烧过程中的烧结，并有效地抑制沸石的酸性。煅烧后清洗催化剂进一步提高了其活性和稳定性，因为水溶性氯化Pt化合物的再分散。高外部表面酸位浓度，特定的Na/Pt原子比，煅烧温度，用水清洗，以及组分引入的顺序都对提高Pt的分散性和催化剂的稳定性有贡献。", "Doi": "10.1016/j.micromeso.2022.112010"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The stability of the Pt particles at the surface of supports can be greatly enhanced by the manipulation of metal-support interaction [9] ,[10] .\"\n          [2] \"The Al2O3 with coordinatively unsaturated pentacoordinate Al3+ (Al3+ penta) sites can stabilize the atomically dispersed Pt specie via the formation of Al3+ penta-O-Pt bond, which results in anchoring Pt particles at the surface of Al2O3 support.\"\n          [3] \"The Pt particles can be tightly stabilized on the heteroatoms in the lattice of oxide substrate [11] .\"\n          [4] \"Small Pt particles stabilized in the lattice-confined Sn (IV/II) produces a highly selective and stable Pt-Sn catalyst for propane dehydrogenation [12] .\"\n          [5] \"Pt particles confined at the Sn single-site in zeolite framework show high catalytic performance in the propane dehydrogenation, and the enhanced performance of Pt/Sn-Beta catalysts is mainly attributed to the strong interaction between the Pt particles and the framework of Sn-zeolite [13] .\"\n          [6] \"The PtSn bimetallic particles are confined in the mesopores, which allow them to become a stable catalyst in propane dehydrogenation at high temperature.\"\n          [7] \"The high efficiency of these PtSn/hierarchical ZSM-5 catalysts for propane dehydrogenation is mainly attributed to the confinement of PtSn particles in the mesopores of hierarchical ZSM-5 zeolite.\"", "English": "The stability of Pt particles on the surface of supports can be significantly improved by manipulating metal-support interactions. Al2O3 with coordinatively unsaturated pentacoordinate Al3+ sites can stabilize atomically dispersed Pt species by forming Al3+ penta-O-Pt bonds, anchoring Pt particles on the Al2O3 surface. Pt particles can also be tightly stabilized on heteroatoms in the oxide substrate lattice. Small Pt particles stabilized in lattice-confined Sn (IV/II) produce a highly selective and stable Pt-Sn catalyst for propane dehydrogenation. Pt particles confined at the Sn single-site in the zeolite framework exhibit high catalytic performance in propane dehydrogenation, mainly due to the strong interaction between Pt particles and the Sn-zeolite framework. The PtSn bimetallic particles confined in the mesopores of hierarchical ZSM-5 zeolite allow them to become a stable catalyst in propane dehydrogenation at high temperatures. The high efficiency of PtSn/hierarchical ZSM-5 catalysts in propane dehydrogenation is mainly attributed to the confinement of PtSn particles in the mesopores of hierarchical ZSM-5 zeolite.", "Chinese": "通过操纵金属-载体相互作用，可以显著提高Pt颗粒在载体表面的稳定性。具有五配位Al3+（Al3+ penta）的Al2O3可以通过形成Al3+ penta-O-Pt键来稳定原子分散的Pt物种，将Pt颗粒锚定在Al2O3表面上。Pt颗粒也可以在氧化物基质的晶格中紧密稳定在杂原子上。在晶格限制的Sn (IV/II)中稳定的小Pt颗粒产生了一种高选择性和稳定的Pt-Sn催化剂，用于丙烷脱氢。在沸石框架中Sn单点处限制的Pt颗粒在丙烷脱氢中表现出高催化性能，增强的性能主要归因于Pt颗粒与Sn-沸石框架之间的强相互作用。PtSn双金属颗粒在分级ZSM-5沸石的介孔中限制，使它们在高温下成为丙烷脱氢的稳定催化剂。PtSn/分级ZSM-5催化剂在丙烷脱氢中的高效率主要归因于PtSn颗粒在分级ZSM-5沸石介孔中的限制。", "Doi": "10.1016/j.cjche.2021.11.020"},
{"Quotes": "Although numerous metal-based and metal oxide-based catalysts show superior activity and selectivity and have been widely developed, it is still unclear and ambiguous as to which active site structures and dehydrogenation mechanisms are followed in the PDH process from a fundamental perspective.\n          In this section, the active sites, dehydrogenation pathways and deactivation mechanisms on Pt-based and representative metal oxide-based catalysts would be clarified.\n          The coordination saturated Pt atoms are more selective for propane dehydrogenation, while the coordinatively unsaturated Pt atoms will catalyze the side reactions, such as CC breaking and deep dehydrogenation, resulting in the formation of carbon deposits.\n          The adsorption configuration and strength of propylene can be both greatly perturbed by surface structures, coke formation is inherently governed by the surface geometric and electronic structures, and thus the construction of specific reaction ensembles is important.\n          Tuning the support's acidity and coke mobility can also inhibit the coke formation.\n          The effective strategies for inhibiting coke are summarized as follows.\n          Geometric separation: Previous research studies have shown that separating the active metal components could inhibit the structure-sensitive side reactions with improved propylene selectivity.\n          Electron richness: A high electron density of Pt particles is beneficial to weaken Pt(CC) bonds, inhibit coke precursors, and suppress deep dehydrogenation and CC cleavage as well, thus promoting desorption of C3H6, leading to a favorable C3H6 selectivity.\n          Poisoning acid sites: In addition to the coke on metal particles, the coke on acidic supports can also suppress the diffusion of reactive molecules.\n          Cofeeding streams: In addition to the modulation of catalyst structures and the properties of supports, changes in reaction conditions by cofeeding streams, such as H2, and CO2, can also have a positive effect on coke elimination.\n          Enhancing oxygen mobility: The oxidation of the adsorbed surface carbonaceous species can help eliminate the coke deposition over supported metals and thus is beneficial to the improvement of catalytic stability.\n          Coke transfer: In addition to inhibiting the coke accumulation on a Pt surface, transferring coke precursors from Pt to supports can also prolong the catalyst life.\n          Their textural properties such as specific surface area, acidbase properties, and thermal stability have been demonstrated to have significant influences on the catalytic performance of Pt-based catalysts.\n          For example, to avert the occurrence of undesirable coke and alkane isomerization on supports, the support acidity should be carefully controlled.\n          Additionally, to increase the dispersion of metal particles, supports with high surface area and uniform pore size distribution are preferred.\n          Some alkaline metals, such as Li, Na, and K, can help poison the strong acid sites and avoid the coke deposition on the Al2O3 surface.\n          Additionally, doping Mg into Al2O3 forms a stable spinel phase.\n          An-Hui Lu and coworkers indicated that Al2O3 nanosheets with abundant penta-coordinate Al atoms have a strong metalsupport interaction owing to their capacity for anchoring Pt atoms, which accounts for their high stability.\n          Due to the weak interaction between Pt and SiO2, Pt-based bimetals with high alloying degrees such as PtM intermetallic alloys can be formed by direct H2 pretreatment on SiO2 supports.\n          Comparatively, there exist strong interactions between CeO2 and metal particles, where Pt atoms can be trapped in the form of Pt ions.\n          Additionally, upon using water vapor, the coke deposition could be eliminated accounting for the redox properties of CeO2 under propane dehydrogenation.\n          The adjustable Si/Al ratios and relatively large surface areas can hinder the formation of large hydrocarbon molecules, thus preventing the so-called coke deposits and improving the catalytic stability.\n          Besides, some mesoporous materials, such as SBA-1561 and MCM-41, are often used as the catalyst supports to disperse the active phase with more active sites and less coke deposition.\n          Two-dimensional (2D) early transition metal carbides, i.e., MXenes, due to their well-defined structures and tunable compositions have attracted much attention.\n          Additionally, carbon materials have been widely used for plenty of reactions because of their large surface area, chemical inertness and stability in acidic/basic media.\n          Novel nanostructured carbon materials including carbon nanotubes and graphene as supports have been gradually developed.\n          Obviously, each specific support has its own characteristic and may exhibit a distinctive effect on the catalytic property.\n          It can not only change the selectivity by influencing the component, morphology and distribution of metal particles but also alter the reaction stability by increasing mechanical strength, anti-sintering and anti-coking resistance.", "English": "The physicochemical properties of catalysts, including chemical qualities and morphological characteristics, significantly influence their performance in dehydrogenation reactions. For instance, the coordination saturation of Pt atoms affects the selectivity of propane dehydrogenation, while the unsaturated Pt atoms can catalyze side reactions, leading to carbon deposition. The adsorption configuration and strength of propylene are closely related to the surface structures, which governs the formation of coke. The acidity and coke mobility of the support also play a role in inhibiting coke formation. Various strategies have been proposed to inhibit coke formation, such as geometric separation, electron richness, poisoning acid sites, cofeeding streams, enhancing oxygen mobility, and coke transfer. The textural properties of supports, such as specific surface area, acid-base properties, and thermal stability, have significant influences on the catalytic performance of Pt-based catalysts. To prevent the occurrence of undesirable coke and alkane isomerization on supports, the support acidity should be carefully controlled. Supports with high surface area and uniform pore size distribution are preferred to increase the dispersion of metal particles. Alkaline metals, such as Li, Na, and K, can help poison the strong acid sites and avoid the coke deposition on the Al2O3 surface. Doping Mg into Al2O3 forms a stable spinel phase. Al2O3 nanosheets with abundant penta-coordinate Al atoms have a strong metal-support interaction owing to their capacity for anchoring Pt atoms, which accounts for their high stability. Due to the weak interaction between Pt and SiO2, Pt-based bimetals with high alloying degrees such as PtM intermetallic alloys can be formed by direct H2 pretreatment on SiO2 supports. Comparatively, there exist strong interactions between CeO2 and metal particles, where Pt atoms can be trapped in the form of Pt ions. Additionally, upon using water vapor, the coke deposition could be eliminated accounting for the redox properties of CeO2 under propane dehydrogenation. The adjustable Si/Al ratios and relatively large surface areas can hinder the formation of large hydrocarbon molecules, thus preventing the so-called coke deposits and improving the catalytic stability. Besides, some mesoporous materials, such as SBA-1561 and MCM-41, are often used as the catalyst supports to disperse the active phase with more active sites and less coke deposition. Two-dimensional (2D) early transition metal carbides, i.e., MXenes, due to their well-defined structures and tunable compositions have attracted much attention. Additionally, carbon materials have been widely used for plenty of reactions because of their large surface area, chemical inertness and stability in acidic/basic media. Novel nanostructured carbon materials including carbon nanotubes and graphene as supports have been gradually developed. Obviously, each specific support has its own characteristic and may exhibit a distinctive effect on the catalytic property. It can not only change the selectivity by influencing the component, morphology and distribution of metal particles but also alter the reaction stability by increasing mechanical strength, anti-sintering and anti-coking resistance.", "Chinese": "催化剂的物理化学性质，包括化学性质和形态特征，对脱氢反应的性能有重大影响。例如，Pt原子的配位饱和度影响丙烷脱氢的选择性，而未饱和的Pt原子可以催化副反应，导致碳沉积。丙烯的吸附构型和强度与表面结构密切相关，这决定了焦炭的形成。支撑材料的酸性和焦炭流动性也在抑制焦炭形成中发挥作用。为了抑制焦炭形成，提出了多种策略，如几何分离、电子丰富性、酸性位点中毒、共进料流、增强氧流动性以及焦炭转移。支撑材料的纹理性质，如比表面积、酸碱性质和热稳定性，对Pt基催化剂的催化性能有显著影响。为了防止在支撑材料上发生不希望的焦炭和烷烃异构化，应仔细控制支撑材料的酸性。为了增加金属颗粒的分散度，优选具有高比表面积和均匀孔径分布的支撑材料。一些碱金属，如Li、Na和K，可以帮助毒化强酸位点，避免在Al2O3表面沉积焦炭。在Al2O3中掺杂Mg形成稳定的尖晶石相。具有丰富五配位Al原子的Al2O3纳米片由于其锚定Pt原子的能力而具有强烈的金属-支撑相互作用，这解释了它们的高稳定性。由于Pt和SiO2之间的弱相互作用，可以通过在SiO2支撑材料上直接H2预处理形成具有高合金度的Pt基双金属，如PtM金属间合金。相比之下，CeO2和金属颗粒之间存在强烈的相互作用，其中Pt原子可以以Pt离子的形式被捕获。此外，通过使用水蒸气，焦炭沉积可以被消除，这归因于CeO2在丙烷脱氢下的氧化还原性质。可调的Si/Al比和相对较大的比表面积可以阻止大烃分子的形成，从而防止所谓的焦炭沉积，提高催化稳定性。此外，一些介孔材料，如SBA-1561和MCM-41，通常用作催化剂支撑材料，以分散活性相，具有更多的活性位点和更少的焦炭沉积。二维（2D）早期过渡金属碳化物，即MXenes，由于其明确定义的结构和可调成分而受到广泛关注。此外，碳材料因其大比表面积、化学惰性和在酸性/碱性介质中的稳定性而被广泛用于大量反应。包括碳纳米管和石墨烯在内的新型纳米结构碳材料作为支撑材料逐渐被开发。显然，每种特定支撑材料都有其自身的特点，可能对催化性能产生独特的影响。它不仅可以改变选择性，影响金属颗粒的成分、形态和分布，还可以通过增加机械强度、抗烧结和抗焦炭性来改变反应稳定性。", "Doi": "10.1039/D0CS00814A"},
{"Quotes": "The surface area-to-metal loading ratio determines which species will form. Indeed, Wu et al. reported that monomeric species are predominantly present below 1.2 V/nm2, polymeric vanadium species prevail between 1.2 and 4.4 V/nm2, and crystalline V2O5 species preponderate at even higher loadings.\n          The reducibility of the vanadium species depends on their molecular structure, VOV and VO bonds being more easily reduced than VO-support bonds.\n          The performance of supported vanadium catalysts can be improved through the addition of MgO, either as a promoter or as a component of a mixed oxide. According to these workers, the increase in dehydrogenation selectivity stems from the basic nature of MgO, resulting in reduced coke formation.\n          Alumina is commonly used as a support for vanadium oxide catalysts, although Sokolov et al. concluded through testing a wide range of Si- and Al-based supports that using silica to dope the alumina support provides beneficial effects on catalyst stability and activity.\n          The chemistry of molybdenum oxide is comparable to that of vanadium oxide, as Mo can be present as MoOx monomers, polymers, or MoO3 crystallites, depending on the molybdenum loading, the type of support used, and catalyst preparation conditions.\n          The reduction of the catalyst with hydrogen prior to reaction increases conversion, although selectivity decreases due to the formation of acid sites.\n          The structure of the support is also important, as a mesoporous GaAl mixed oxide exhibited an increased resistance to catalyst coking.\n          The function of K was to reduce coke formation by poisoning Brnsted acid sites.\n          Alumina is by far the most common support, and a variety of methods to produce chromiaalumina catalysts have been investigated.\n          The nature of the support is important not only because it governs the mechanical properties of the catalyst, but also because the interaction of the carrier with the active phase can have a profound impact on catalyst activity and selectivity.\n          Albeit all of the noble metals of group VIIIB are active in the nonoxidative hydrogenation of alkanes, Pt is the only noble metal utilized in commercial applications due to its superior activation of paraffinic CH bonds and low activity to CC cleavage.\n          Indeed, it has been observed that Cr5+ species that are not reduced in a hydrogen atmosphere can be reduced by alkanes.\n          The use of zirconia as an alternative support has also been investigated.\n          The use of silica as the support in chromia-based dehydrogenation catalysts requires a relative high surface area to stabilize Cr6+ sites.\n          CrMgAl and CrMg mixed oxides prepared using layered double hydroxide (LDH) precursors have been studied as catalysts for the nonoxidative dehydrogenation of ethane.\n          Finally, the study of porous chromia-pillared α-zirconium phosphate materials has been particularly informative with regards to the influence that acidity has on catalytic behavior.\n          The surface area-to-metal loading ratio determines which species will form. Indeed, Wu et al. reported that monomeric species are predominantly present below 1.2 V/nm2, polymeric vanadium species prevail between 1.2 and 4.4 V/nm2, and crystalline V2O5 species preponderate at even higher loadings.\n          On the one hand, the presence of hydroxyl groups on the surface of the support is important to obtain a well-dispersed catalyst, as OH groups serve as anchoring sites for the vanadium precursors used to prepare these catalysts. On the other hand, acid sites are detrimental for catalyst performance, because they facilitate cracking and induce coke formation.\n          Alumina is commonly used as a support for vanadium oxide catalysts, although Sokolov et al. concluded through testing a wide range of Si- and Al-based supports that using silica to dope the alumina support provides beneficial effects on catalyst stability and activity.\n          Furthermore, as was shown by Harlin et al., the performance of supported vanadium catalysts can be improved through the addition of MgO, either as a promoter or as a component of a mixed oxide. According to these workers, the increase in dehydrogenation selectivity stems from the basic nature of MgO, resulting in reduced coke formation.\n          The reducibility of the vanadium species depends on their molecular structure, VOV and VO bonds being more easily reduced than VO-support bonds.\n          The chemistry of molybdenum oxide is comparable to that of vanadium oxide, as Mo can be present as MoOx monomers, polymers, or MoO3 crystallites, depending on the molybdenum loading, the type of support used, and catalyst preparation conditions.\n          Harlin et al. noted that optimal activity was achieved with monolayer coverage of molybdenum oxide on an alumina support.\n          The reduction of the catalyst with hydrogen prior to reaction increases conversion, although selectivity decreases due to the formation of acid sites.\n          The exact nature of the active sites in Ga-based dehydrogenation catalysts is still under debate. Akin to Al2O3, Ga2O3 has different polymorphs of which β-Ga2O3 is not only the most stable, but also the most active Ga species in PDH according to some authors.\n          β-Ga2O3 has a monoclinic structure, in which gallium atoms are equally distributed between tetrahedral and octahedral configurations. This crystal structure has a high concentration of weak Lewis acid sites (coordinatively unsaturated tetrahedral ones on the surface of the material), which are deemed to be centers of dehydrogenation activity.\n          The assignment of Lewis acid sites as the active species was substantiated by Chen et al., who, by relating the results of NH3-TPD measurements with activity data for different GaxAl10xO15 mixed oxides, showed that a high concentration of Lewis acid groups in the form of coordinatively unsaturated tetrahedral Ga3+ cations is a prerequisite for dehydrogenation activity.\n          Xu et al. reported dehydrogenation activity on both Lewis and Brnsted acid sites on GaO3/H-ZSM-5. A zeolitic support displaying a low concentration of medium and strong acid sites and a relatively high concentration of weak acid sites was found to lead to the most active and stable catalyst.\n          Michorczyk et al. concluded that acidic groups catalyze the reaction after observing that promotion with a base, such as potassium, resulted in a decrease in activity.\n          The structure of the support is also important, as a mesoporous GaAl mixed oxide exhibited an increased resistance to catalyst coking.\n          The function of K was to reduce coke formation by poisoning Brnsted acid sites.\n          Pt is believed to act as a promoter for the GaOx. Indeed, albeit 1000 ppm Pt/Al2O3 was found to be virtually inactive, 1000 ppm of Pt in combination with 3 wt % Ga afforded conversions close to the equilibrium and an propylene selectivity <95%.\n          The role of Pt is to assist hydrogen desorption, which facilitates the regeneration of the gallium hydride hydroxide species.\n          The exact nature of the active sites in Ga-based dehydrogenation catalysts is still under debate.\n          The chemistry of molybdenum oxide is comparable to that of vanadium oxide, as Mo can be present as MoOx monomers, polymers, or MoO3 crystallites, depending on the molybdenum loading, the type of support used, and catalyst preparation conditions.\n          The reducibility of the catalyst with hydrogen prior to reaction increases conversion, although selectivity decreases due to the formation of acid sites.\n          The chemistry of molybdenum oxide is comparable to that of vanadium oxide, as Mo can be present as MoOx monomers, polymers, or MoO3 crystallites, depending on the molybdenum loading, the type of support used, and catalyst preparation conditions.\n          The reducibility of the catalyst with hydrogen prior to reaction increases conversion, although selectivity decreases due to the formation of acid sites.\n          The chemistry of molybdenum oxide is comparable to that of vanadium oxide, as Mo can be present as MoOx monomers, polymers, or MoO3 crystallites, depending on the molybdenum loading, the type of support used, and catalyst preparation conditions.\n          The reducibility of the catalyst with hydrogen prior to reaction increases conversion, although selectivity decreases due to the formation of acid sites.\n          The chemistry of molybdenum oxide is comparable to that of vanadium oxide, as Mo can be present as MoOx monomers, polymers, or MoO3 crystallites, depending on the molybdenum loading, the type of support used, and catalyst preparation conditions.\n
